data.title: The Lovely Tide
data.content:
During filming in India there was the core crew of three guys, myself included, there for five weeks. During the last ten days, two more came from America--Nathan and Jack.

We were returning from our trip north, and as we walked through the darkness of the field towards the orphanage's rec center lights, I could hear the shouts of the kids. We crept up the steps, trying to sneak up on them, but Muney saw one of us and shouted and we were swept up in a tide of adoring, wriggling kids, saying, "Enna (older brother) we thought you go to America. Enna come back, good."

I looked over the heads of the kids and saw Nathan and Jack standing there, smiling. It seemed wrong to me that they were there--and I struggled to hide it from them as they came over to hug us and talk excitedly about the two days they'd been with the kids while we'd been gone. They kept telling us things we already knew. And I started getting annoyed, and for an instant I wondered if the kids liked them more than they liked me. I thought, well, I'm not much of a kid person, anyway and immediately upon thinking that Vignesh come up to me, threw his arms around my waist, pressing the side of his face against me. "I missed you so much" he said.

A harsh light was thrown on me. I saw how petty and small I was being. I was afraid somebody would see written on my face how scared I was that the kids had forgotten us, afraid that the beginnings of love they had shown would have withered in our absence.

And that was the case so many times. The honesty of the children humbled me, humiliated me even. I couldn't stand to look them in the eyes, sometimes, for fear of what they would see in mine. But they never looked away.

I was reading the famous Corinthian love verses recently--"Love is not jealous or boastful or proud" (1 Corinthians 13:4)--and this is what I realized: that there will always be a mean, insecure, jealous voice inside of me. It's dumb to expect otherwise, in this world. Even when Vignesh hugged me, it did not go away, it didn't even get quiet; it was simply that love roared up in me, strong as an army, until I couldn't hear that stupid, fearful voice anymore.

Silas

data.title: Doritos
data.content:
In his Popeye frame of abnormally-sized muscles paired with balding, loose-skinned head, a man of barely 5' 5" would climb onto his desk. From the back of his over-caffeinated throat he emitted in a raspy scream, "SLOTHS! YOU'RE ALL A BUNCH OF SLOTHS!" That was my US History teacher.

I've always had in my mind a lazy person deserved that kind of scolding. Lazy people sit around eating Doritos and playing video games and don't have jobs. I've had jobs. I keep busy. I stay involved. At least I used to before I moved from the big city of Chicago to a suburb in Northeast Ohio.

For some reason it's harder now for me to call people or even get to the doctor's office. I feel lethargic. I'm frustrated. What changed? Where did my energy go?

I wanted God to tell me how to find that passion again and something made me start reading through Proverbs about laziness. I began to realize everything that kept me busy in the past didn't require that much of me. As many activities and friends as I had, I didn't have to go out of my way to gain any of it. And now that I do, I find myself unwilling.

I'm sure some Winnie the Pooh book or Berenstain Bears movie told me this once; that nothing good comes easily. It goes two ways: anything worthwhile is worth working for and anything not worthwhile...well, probably isn't very rewarding.

So when I think about my sickly friendships, I'm starting to feel like I should just call Carly instead of whining about feeling far away from her. When I feel useless maybe I should just go to the food bank, instead of crying over my lack of motivation.

"Despite their desires, the lazy will come to ruin, for their hands refuse to work" (Proverbs 21:25).

Come on hands, let's go.

June

data.title: Work for Peace
data.content:
In the Middle East, the desire for peace is wound into the skin of the culture like hummus and pita bread. Shalom. Salaam. "Peace." You can't say hi to somebody there without filling up the air with the idea of this thing that is not but, "oh, if only it could be."

My friend Amir is Israeli. I asked him once if he had ever been personally affected by terrorism, if he had ever known someone who had died. "Of course," he said, "everybody has." As simple as that.

In some way the answer is the same for all of us. Have you ever been personally affected by this wretched turmoil of struggling through conflict and pain and things being not as they should be?

"Of course. Everybody has."

"God's peace exceeds anything we can understand" (Philippians 4:7).

Until peace grows out of the ground like food that can feed the whole world. Until our relationships are mended. Until our angst is calmed. Until Jesus finally makes peace as real as the hellos that remind us of it.

Until then.

A longing. A hope. A tiny taste of what will one day be. And something well worth working for in the meantime.

Peace.

"Turn away from evil and do good. Search for peace, and work to maintain it" (Psalm 34:14).

Em

data.title: Funny Disciples
data.content:
I wonder if the disciples would have signed up for the job if they had known how embarrassing it would be to have Jesus repeatedly expose their frail, clumsy, narcissistic humanity. And then have it written down in the best-selling book of all time.

One of my favorites is in Mark 9 (and then exactly one chapter later in Mark 10) when their response to Jesus saying, "I'm going to be killed soon" is to call "shotgun" to sit in the front seat of the kingdom.

The first time, at least, they had the decency to be embarrassed at arguing over who was the greatest like a bunch of middle school basketball players. (I remember that debate vividly; I lost.)

The second time, though, James and John (and their mom) outraged the other ten when they made their play right to the Master himself: "When you sit on your glorious throne, we want to sit in places of honor next to you, one on your right and the other on your left" (Mark 10:37).

Jesus' response both times: "Whoever wants to be first must take last place and be the servant of everyone else" (Mark 9:35).

Mostly, we give the disciples a pass because they just didn't get it--and then they made up for it by living and dying to serve Jesus and all of Christendom.

But I do know who Jesus really is and that he came to be first by being last. And I'm no apostle destined to die for my faith.

So is it still funny that my frail, clumsy, narcissistic humanity shows up just as obvious and ugly? Would a biographer make comic hay of the way I jockey with my wife over who does dishes or spends most or admits guilt first?

Apparently, on many days, I do not want to be first, even in my own house, if that means being last in my own house.

That's hilarious, right?

Hank

data.title: You Are a Wonderful Person
data.content:
"Dis is whar I come from." my friend, Avi, laughed deep. Like the roots of trees. And continued in his thick Ethiopian accent. "See," he said, "we 'ad no shoes." He laughed again. "Jesus tho. 'e is the best. 'e everything."

He pressed his hand against his chest and his black dreadlocks danced like they were doorbeads barely veiling some secret party he was having inside of himself.

I never met anyone who was so wistful and contagious in his love for Jesus. Which was surprising. Because Avi had a life that was anything but wistful. He had grown up in Ethiopia and made an immigration to Israel with thousands of other oppressed families in the '80s.

He landed in Tel Aviv. Lived on the streets. Raised himself up that little ladder: a struggle for power mixed with drugs and money and all the stories he doesn't like to tell anymore. He did pretty well...apparently. But what does 'well' mean when you get to the top and find the view rather disappointing? I knew about disappointing views.

I stayed up late hearing Avi's story. He told me that he was meeting his sister the next day. A sister he hadn't known existed until a couple days before. Every few minutes he would look up and say "Jesus" like it was the name of some secret he was afraid he'd forget.

When I got up to leave, he told me "You are a wonderful person." He paused. "And messed up." We both knew that he was reminding me. After all, being messed up and being loved anyway is one of the best parts of what Jesus does.

"He knows how weak we are.... But"--and what a great place for a contrasting conjunction, "the love of the LORD remains forever" (Psalm 103:14, 17).

And that is very worth laughing about. Deep. Like the roots of trees.

Em

data.title: Dirty Old Snake
data.content:
"Then the Lord God asked the woman, 'What have you done?' 'The serpent deceived me,' she replied. 'That's why I ate it'" (Genesis 3:13).

I really don't need a snake to trick me into screwing things up. I am more than capable of doing that all on my own. I can tell myself to have too much to drink, to lie about being sick to get out of things, to use God's name when I'm not talking to him or about him. I can tell secrets about someone close to me. I can make a mess of things without any help from some old snake, thank you very much.

I was born this way, and it's never been hard for me.

We've all found ways of justifying our sin, just like that snake whispered to Eve. We are all professional justifiers.

I look at pornography to appreciate the beauty of women.
I can stop whenever I want to.
Jesus drank wine.
I just had to tell someone.
I hate them because they're evil.
God wants me to be happy (rich, successful, etc.).
I'm still better than _________ (insert name).

I don't have to be like this. I can escape from this hissing carousel; I can run back to God. I can get away from the life that dirty snake whispers to me about.

Doug

data.title: Exiled to Adulthood
data.content:
When I was a kid or before I was an adult, (I'm not sure exactly when one ended and the other began) I felt a destination in front of me. I labeled that destination adulthood. I assumed when I got there, I would find marriage, children, and fulfillment waiting for me, much as if I arrived in New York City I would find the Empire State Building, Times Square, and the Statue of Liberty.

Well, at thirty-two I assume I've hit adulthood. I'm still waiting to feel like I've arrived. While I've seen some of the sights--marriage, children--and I've accomplished a few things I set out to do, I can't say I feel like I'm there. Instead, I feel directionless, like maybe I took a wrong turn and missed New York City altogether. I feel displaced. At least before I was here, I had some where to go. Now I find myself wandering somewhat aimlessly, even, sometimes, hopelessly.

Jeremiah 29:11 says, "'For I know the plans I have for you,' says the LORD. 'They are plans for good and not for disaster, to give you a future and a hope.'" When I feel hopeless I rely on that verse. As I read it this time, though, the context struck me. It's written to exiles in Babylon. After God promised them a future in which they wouldn't be exiles, he told them to settle in, plant crops, have children and to "work for the peace and prosperity of the city where I sent you into exile."

I love that. It means that not only was there a future for the exiles, who surely felt more displaced than I do, but that they could, in the meantime, enjoy where they were. They didn't have to struggle for the future. He had promised it and would fulfill it when the time came. Meanwhile, they were supposed to do the everyday things that make life work. Have babies, plant gardens, live life, pass the time. It gives me permission to do the same.

Ellen

data.title: Possessors of Truth
data.content:
"Jesus told him, 'I am the way, the truth, and the life'" (John 14:6).

It's easy to think we can't know the truth--our beings are predicated by locality and perspective. We see a tiny portion of what is going on. And we see that small portion, often, tragically inaccurately.

Not only are we blind to those things far away from us, we also have a tough time seeing the things very close to us clearly. Our friends, our families, the people we live with, they are all obscured by the past knowledge we have of them.

But we believe in a God who is Truth, whose very nature defines truth, whose very being exists outside all the ways we know of defining truth. How then does this help us? We lack the apparatus to receive such a God.

Thankfully, we are granted, through Jesus, a manner in which to perceive the Holy without getting our eyes burnt out. But a problem occurs almost immediately with this contact.

When humans, used as we are to doubt and a lack of surety, get a glimpse of truth, our natural desire to possess things comes into play, and we start to think that, because we have seen the truth by which our lives are to be measured, we therefore possess that truth, that yardstick.

This is wrong, because even if you go farther than glimpsing that truth, and God takes up his residence and makes you his temple, mingles with your blood, you do not own him. This is why people blow up government buildings, or hate gays and Muslims: they think they own the standards of life.

What are the greatest commandments?

At times we seem to forget.

Silas

data.title: Recognized
data.content:
I have Gilmore Girls to thank, really. There's this scene in an early season where two main characters that are best friends, get in a fight. When they make up later, one of them says, "Let's never do that again!" I was watching with my close non-believing friend, Amanda. She looked at me and said, "I feel like we don't ever fight." I agreed. Then Amanda said, "Not like you and Stephanie."

Stephanie is one of my closest friends who believes and loves Jesus. We'd recently had some heated discussions about our faith. She doesn't like how close I am with Amanda; I feel like she treats non-Christians as projects. She wants her pastor to teach right and wrong answers, clear doctrine. I want my pastor to teach what the Bible says, even if people tend to live out those teachings in different ways. I never thought Stephanie was being deceived or anything drastic like that. I just wanted to point out to her how elementary her beliefs were. I wanted her to see that Christians can't all think and act the same, by insisting that she think and act the same as I do.

"Now regarding your question about food that has been offered to idols. Yes, we know that "we all have knowledge" about this issue. But while knowledge makes us feel important, it is love that strengthens the church. Anyone who claims to know all the answers doesn't really know very much. But the person who loves God is the one whom God recognizes" (1 Corinthians 8:1-3).

Love is more important than knowledge. Even if I think my nuanced understandings of the parables are more accurate. Even if I believe my more complex applications of the Bible are more sensible. It is my love that will strengthen, not my knowledge.

It wasn't until Amanda said, "not like you and Stephanie," that I knew something was wrong. But it took me a few weeks to figure out what. I had not loved Stephanie. I had valued my cleverness above everything else. And for all my scholarly ways, I had missed a key truth. Something it took very little endeavor and cunning to find. "Three things will last forever--faith, hope, and love--and the greatest of these is love" (1 Corinthians 13:13).

June

data.title: Persecution, American-Style
data.content:
There was a curious exchange on Facebook yesterday. At least, as curious as Facebook exchanges can get. It involved a friend of mine--who I'll call Adam--and someone I do not know, Mike. Mike posted a status about the current president's "war on religion" and Adam retorted by saying that there is no such thing and you can imagine the direction things went from there. Mike said the persecution of Christians is alive and well in America. Adam said that the term "persecution" must be stretched mighty thin to apply to America's treatment of Christianity. Mike said Adam was apathetic, holding the cross in contempt. Adam responded: "wow."

It was heated in the way online conversations are heated: blustery, self-righteous, and over as soon as both sides ran out of vocabulary. A short, sad, stupid story. Except, I happen to know a little background.

Adam was once a Christian. Or, sort of still is, or something. He's not too sure himself, and I won't put words in his mouth. I remember a few months when he let me live with him when I had no place to stay. He'd pace the floor, debating himself out loud. He wanted to believe but couldn't rationalize it. We can sympathize, many of us.

Christians themselves, most of them, didn't help much. When he was still certain of his Christianity but open about his struggles, some told him that he couldn't possibly be a Christian if he was still doubting. And now, some years later, those barbs seem to have nearly convinced him.

After the Facebook fight had smoldered down to a smoking pile, he said "I'd be lying if I said this stuff never hurt." I know what kind of stuff he's talking about. We have become adept in dressing cruel sentiments in flowery Christian words. The whole Bible, reduced to a series of talking points for our next argument.

And I thought to myself, whatever persecution there is of Christians in this country cannot be nearly as damaging as persecution by Christians in this country.

"Dear friends, let us continue to love one another, for love come from God. Anyone who loves is a child of God and knows God" (1 John 4:7).

Joe

data.title: Other People
data.content:
Last night I curled up behind my friend on her bed. Holding her like a fetus in my womb. Her body shook and I could feel her hot tears on my finger tips as I moved along her face wanting my body to be close enough to circulate my blood with hers. To transfer peace like infusion. But I could not.

She flipped her body. Facing me. In the dark, she moved my hand to her mouth. "See." she said. "See how happy it will be." I could feel her smile like a Halloween costume. "Would you forgive me? It's the one part of my plan that is not working. You will not believe me."

"What won't I believe?"

"That it would be better. But we won't talk about it. I made a pact." she added a half-teaspoon of assurance. "I'm going to be a good girl."

Panic attacks, anxiety, lack of concentration, insomnia. A tiny bit of alcohol abuse, severe hopelessness, the idealization of suicide.

These are the sterilized descriptors I read in journal articles, the contributing factors of suicide cases within one year. I cannot breathe.

I put my hands against her temples like a vice. "It would devastate me. I love you so much."

I have no idea why this dark thing creeps along the perimeters and into the viewfinder and up into the lap and soul of my precious friend. Why does she have this burden? Why this hungry parasite of her life?

"Levy" she named it. This Levy that I hate. Levy that I would rise up and kill in the night like Jael. And I would. I would kill this thing. I fantasize about not being helpless.

It is harder to trust God with other people than it is to trust God with ourselves.

"Praise the LORD, who did not let their teeth tear us apart! We escaped like a bird from a hunter's trap. The trap is broken, and we are free! Our help is from the LORD, who made heaven and earth" (Psalm 124:6-8).

Em

data.title: My Lot in Life
data.content:
I'm the middle kid in my family. I have a big sister and a baby brother. My sister is beautiful.

I have always felt a little like a knock-off copy of her. People say we look alike, but to me the differences are glaring. Her clothes are two sizes smaller. Her bra is two sizes larger. Her hair is at least three inches longer. Her tan is several shades darker. Besides that she has an interesting career and models on the side.

She came from Omaha to see me in Dallas this weekend, and I was once again stunned at how her looks seem to improve as she ages. My old fears of being seen as the lesser copy of the perfect original came back as I introduced her to my circle of friends at a barbeque. I was sure they would start comparing and see that I wasn't as beautiful or interesting as she is. I felt myself beginning to shrink as my little-sister-complex grew.

Ecclesiastes has a way of making sense of things that don't make sense, by simply saying everything is "like chasing after wind." The solution to this futility is to "accept your lot in life" and enjoy what you have. Ecclesiastes 9:6-7 says, "Whatever [people] did in their lifetime--loving, hating, envying--is all long gone...So go ahead. Eat your food and drink your wine with a happy heart, for God approves of this." So the time I spend envying will only keep me from enjoying, and God approves of my enjoyment. So envy disappoints God because he knows it keeps me from joy.

The night of the barbeque, my friends engaged me as much as usual. When I talked with them, I didn't see the expected disappointment in their eyes. I realized I was the only one comparing my sister and myself. I started to relax and enjoy. In the end, I had a great night. Would have been a shame to miss it because of envy.

Ellen

data.title: Forgive Others
data.content:
I am not overstating it when I say that the man who caused all the trouble hurt all of you more than he hurt me. Most of you opposed him, and that was punishment enough. Now, however, it is time to forgive and comfort him. Otherwise he may be overcome by discouragement. So I urge you now to reaffirm your love for him.
2 Corinthians 2:5-8

data.content:

data.title: Crave More than Milk
data.content:
Dear brothers and sisters, when I was with you I couldn't talk to you as I would to spiritual people. I had to talk as though you belonged to this world or as though you were infants in the Christian life. I had to feed you with milk, not with solid food because you weren't ready for anything stronger. And you still aren't ready, for you are still controlled by your sinful nature. You are jealous of one another and quarrel with each other. Doesn't that prove you are controlled by your sinful nature? Aren't you living like people of the world?
1 Corinthians 3:1-3
data.questions:
What is the indicator that these people are spiritually immature?

Do you find some relationships to be challenging? How do you handle this?

data.title: Hurt Me
data.content:
I laughed a little and shuffled my head around on our pillow.
"Why did you lie to me?"
"You don’t expect me to tell you after every time I mess up, do you?" he asks.

He started being tempted about one week before I asked him to install one of those pornography surveillance programs on our computer.

"I almost didn't want to install it, just to leave the door open...in case I ever wanted to look in the future."

"Well, I kind of feel like that's what not telling me does--leaves the door open. So you kind of have the emotional freedom to choose it again."

I don't enjoy saying something I know will hurt my husband. I usually rush and fumble through it all. But I do it. I tell him because I know I should. He's the one who told me that, in marriage, you have to be willing sometimes to say things that hurt the other person.

"'In the future your children will ask you, "What is the meaning of these laws, decrees, and regulations that the Lord our God has commanded us to obey?"

"Then you must tell them, 'We were Pharaoh's slaves in Egypt, but the LORD brought us out of Egypt with his strong hand...And the LORD our God commanded us to obey all these decrees and to fear him so he can continue to bless us and preserve our lives...'" (Deuteronomy 6).

When I argue with myself about whether being honest even matters to God, I remember why he commanded us to holy and honest living--why he wants our obedience even if it means initially hurting those we love most. Because he freed us from our captivity to sin. God wants us to experience what we can of beauty and truthfulness in this life. He wants to give us good things.

June

data.title: Sex as Sacrifice
data.content:
The thing I never expected was not wanting to have sex.

There's this classic Christian-dude's-dorm-room thing where guys say "When I get married, we’re just gonna have sex day and night, like 6 times a day. At least." And I knew that was completely false, simply because, well, I couldn't imagine any woman wanting to have sex six times a day with these guys. Just didn't seem likely.

But wanting an orgasm and wanting sex aren't the same thing. I may very well want an orgasm six times a day, but in my marriage, I found sex to be an extremely vulnerable, emotionally intimidating and overall exhausting activity.

And I shouldn't have been surprised, but I was. My sexual experiences up to the point of my marriage consisted of pornography, masturbation and guilty back-seat fondling with girlfriends. Everything was focused on my God-given and quickly distorted desire to have an orgasm.

But in marriage, sex isn't just the reward, it's part of the work. Sex is a point of union, and there are times when you don't want to talk to your spouse, let alone make love to her. The Biblical requisite to have sex seemed unnecessary before I was married, but now I see its importance. Sex is often sacrificial, and that's not what I wanted it to be.

So I'm working on this one: "husbands...love your wives, just as Christ loved the church. He gave up his life for her..." (Ephesians 5:25). As my wife and I work to grow closer sexually, I see the fruit of that work--a mysterious, blossoming oneness.*

And for those of you who aren't married, don't think that your potential spouse is going to be the thing you've been fantasizing about.

She'll be something better. Something real. Something worth working for.

Sam

* "This explains why a man leaves his father and mother and is joined to his wife, and the two are united into one. Now the man and his wife were both naked, and they felt no shame" (Genesis 2:24-25).

data.title: A Dream
data.content:
I do not believe that all dreams are from God, or even most. But this dream, whether or not it was from God, was certainly interesting.

I dreamed that I was on some sort of ship, the sort Columbus or Blackbeard might have sailed on. And there was a vast and violent storm and the ship kept shooting up nearly vertical with waves much bigger than the boat. I, along with several others, was scrambling hand over hand to tie down cargo and lower the sails. At the helm, the captain had both hands on the wheel, attempting to keep course.

A crack of lightning illuminated the twisting, sloping ocean around us, all gray and split by great waves and, disconcertingly, split-second views of menacing shadows under the water that looked troublingly like creatures waiting for a snack.

(Here might be an appropriate time to tell you that I have a crippling fear of those giant sea creatures you're always seeing in movies or old, nautical maps. Thusly armed, let’s move on.)

Tossed around like a sack of marbles, I struggled up the deck towards the helm, to where our captain stood, both feet firmly planted despite the heaving waves, mysteriously steady despite the storm, his eyes fixed on the horizon.

"Captain!" I yelled, throwing myself to his feet. "Save us! We won’t make it!"

"Courage, boy!" he said, his voice deep and gravelly. "Can't you see I've already saved you?"

And I looked and saw that he had nailed his feet to the deck and his hands to the wheel.

"Besides," he said, with a great laugh, "this is how the ocean is supposed to be. Why else would I be taking you home?"

And I woke up, late for work.

"God, for whom and through whom everything was made, chose to bring many children into glory. And it was only right that he should make Jesus, through his suffering, a perfect leader, fit to bring them into their salvation" (Hebrews 2:10).

Joe

data.title: Seeing Sorrow
data.content:
My sister is two years older than I am. Growing up we went to a small school and participated in all the same activities. Because I was two years behind her, I was always learning what she already knew. When I made the varsity volleyball team, she was captain and that scenario repeated itself all through my adolescence. I felt behind and little most of the time. That, plus the fact that she’s beautiful and elegant, bred in me a deep sense of jealousy.

The ugliest part of jealousy is that it makes you unable to celebrate with whomever you're jealous of. You can't be happy for them because you're too busy feeling behind in the competition you've created. In my relationship with my sister, it also blinded me to her pain. As we became adults, my jealousy became emotional distance. We talked often, but I kept a "safe" self-protective space between us.

A few years ago, my sister decided to file for divorce after eight years of marriage. Those eight years were filled with painful emotional abuse, difficult fertility treatments, a miscarriage and lots of hard work. One night shortly after the divorce we were talking, and I saw all of that. I saw her pain, and I cried with her. Something in me loosened that night. All of my resentment at what I saw as her superiority unraveled. I realized the pain she had been carrying by herself while I begrudged her happiness.

Romans chapter 12 talks about how to fully experience life as the body of Christ. Verse 15 says, "Be happy with those who are happy, and weep with those who weep." Jealousy made that impossible for me. It took seeing and sharing my sister's sadness to make me capable of desiring happiness for her.

Ellen

data.title: I'm a Sinner
data.content:
We're sinners. Every one of us. And it's ok to admit that.

1 John 1:8-9

If we claim we have no sin, we are only fooling ourselves and not living in the truth. But if we confess our sins to him, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all wickedness.

That means no matter what you've done, God will forgive it. The greater that sin, the greater that makes our God.

data.title: The Faculty Divine
data.content:
I've been reading about sight. About how light falls through the pupil onto the photoreceptor cells of the retina, which release chemicals that send pulses of electric energy through the optic chiasm (a twisting bundle of nerves) to the visual cortex wherein millions upon millions of cells convert the energy of light into fluid vision of the world.

The light worms its way deep into what we think of as ourselves, our heads, our brains...while we just sit there stupidly and see.

The delicate suspension of our bodies frightens me. I feel strangely precarious, as if this whole business could fail at any moment, as if the bindings of my cells could dissolve and I'd drift away on some slight wind.

And not just me. This place, Earth, it can seem so bland and of course at times. But Venus, our sister-planet, the one scientists thought most likely to support life, turned out to be a hell-hole. Besides the poisonous vapors, thick gaseous clouds, and a crushing surface pressure greater than that at the bottom of the deepest ocean trenches, it rains acid. Literally acid.

Yet here, it rains water. That's something to consider. Each day and thing here is composed of miraculous character, of uncertain balance.

And yet we swirl, bored and heavy, on our planet swinging silently through space.

Reading about the machinations of sight forces me to consider many things. I should respect people for what they are, individual miracles. The days I spend ungratefully are an affront to the God who has lent me the spirit of life. Like Jacob, I should wake from sleep and say:

"Surely the Lord is in this place, and I wasn't even aware of it!" But he was also afraid and said, "What an awesome place this is! It is none other than the house of God, the very gateway to heaven!" (Genesis 28:16-17).

Silas

data.title: Beggars Searching for Bread
data.content:
I think it's interesting when guys tell me "I would never cheat on my wife." Interesting because most of us would, in fact, cheat on our wives. Most definitely. And human nature tells me that if someone wants to do something they are very likely to do just that*.

Here's why.

Your wife isn't going to fulfill your every fantasy. She's not your perfect match. She can actually be really annoying when she's (x),(y) and especially (z). And she really needs to stop trying to change you.

Enter her. She laughs at the jokes your wife thinks are adolescent. When you flirt with her, you feel confident. Her body, whether objectively more or less attractive, is at the very least different. Scented with something you can’t quite put your finger on.

At the base of every human relationship there lies disappointment. I have a wonderful time with my wife--great sex, great arguments, wonderful experiences--but I am occasionally struck by how incredibly unfulfilled I still feel as a person. When I met her, I was tempted to think that she would fill some deep void in me and now that I know she can't, I start to look elsewhere.

There is no human being who offers the depth of acceptance, meaning and fulfillment I crave. My spouse won't fulfill that need and neither will my co-worker.

I watched a skit once where a husband and wife had to realize that they were both beggars searching for bread. When they stopped demanding sustenance from each other, they found peace in the mutual pursuit of nourishment from the One who actually has something real:

"My purpose is to give them a rich and satisfying life" (John 10:10).

No one else can offer that. Not even her.

Sam

* "The human heart is the most deceitful of all things, and desperately wicked. Who really knows how bad it is?" (Jeremiah 17:9).

data.title: Stupid Bed
data.content:
I usually sleep pretty well. I look forward to hitting the pillow and mostly wake up when the alarm tells me (or nine minutes later when it tells me again). But I've had times when my bed has betrayed me.

No matter how exhausted I was, it wouldn't support my sleep. Too tired to get up but too freaked out to lose consciousness again, my bed felt like a prison. How was I going to tell my wife I didn't get this job, either? How would she react when I told her we might have to sell the house, move away? What happens when you don't pay your electric bill? How long does a woman keep believing in you before she gives up?

My bed had no answers. I could only lay there and agonize.

That's why David's words in Psalm 6:1-10 (NIV) resonate so loudly to me. It feels like it was written in the middle of the night by a man scrawling out painful prayers under a blanket of anxious fear.

"I am worn out from groaning." "All night long I flood my bed with weeping." "My eyes grow weak with sorrow."

Somewhere in the darkness, though, David makes a choice. Two choices, really. Okay, three.

First, he chooses to fling his frustration toward God as a desperate plea for help with whatever had gripped his heart. (It sounds like guilt to me. And fear. Maybe both.)

His next choice is to make it a song: "My soul is in anguish. How long, LORD, how long?" He didn't hold back. He put his ugly fears and feelings right out there.

And then he believed: "The LORD has heard my cry for mercy; the LORD accepts my prayer."

Will I believe him before I see how he'll fix it? I want to.

It's not a magic potion, but it makes it a little easier for me somehow to mumble through Psalm 6 with David in the darkness, a little less frantic in my stupid bed. And even if the alarm still won't buzz soon enough, I know God’s heard me.

Hank

data.title: Sun and Rain
data.content:
I feel exhausted, worn and old. I'm growing familiar with being forgotten and it leaves me empty and dry. I've moved around a lot, so most of my friends are used to living without me. Naturally, friends in my current city end up cancelling a lot. They don’t call back or arrange other times to get together. For months now I've been telling myself it's what I'm supposed to do. I initiate everything and go out of my way to follow through.

I lay weathered and weakened on my living room couch. That's it. I give up. If you want to call me, you do it. And we'll see if I even pick up. I figured eventually they'd give back. And I didn't think I'd get tired so quickly.

"You have heard the law that says, 'Love your neighbor' and hate your enemy. But I say, love your enemies! ...In that way, you will be acting as true children of your Father in heaven. For he gives his sunlight to both the evil and the good, and he sends rain on the just and the unjust alike" (Matthew 5).

God gives sun for warmth and rain for nourishment to both people who love him and to people who neglect him. He draws no lines. The Pharisees asked him once, "Who's my neighbor?" because they wanted lines. They want Jesus to say, "It's okay to slap someone back once and a while." But he'll never say that. He’ll insist instead, to let hurtful people bring out the best in you.

It's fine if I get tired of chasing down friends. A lot of relationships end eventually. But I can't lash out in revenge, ignoring their calls and 'forgetting' them back. Unless I believe that God would do the same. That he'd withhold the sun and rain because he's tired of loving people who abandon him.

In the few opportunities I have to look like a holy God in this world, I think picking up a phone call is a rather easy one. Now I just have to work on my reasons for picking up…

June

data.title: Storytoppers
data.content:
Confession: I'm one arrogant son-of-a-gun. That arrogance has manifested itself in my life in manifold witness, but generally occurs in a sort of hackneyed seesaw between self-loathing and smug (if tepid) self-assurance. And whether I despise or find great pleasure in myself, I can always be relied upon to talk about myself, at great length and to the considerable discomfort of others.

All this is to say: I understand you, storytoppers. I understand you because I'm one of you. I, Sam-not-allowed-to-share-my-real-name, I am a storytopper and I am calling us to stop it, now, before it’s too late.

Exhibit A.
Facebook Status update (I jest not):

Dan Somebody: Just got finished worshipping for the first time at New York Tabernacle! Awesome!

Storytopper: Been there twice.

Exhibit B.
Jenny Soandso: I’m so excited for my trip to England this fall!

Storytopper: My summers there were always so great--England really helped form my sense of self.

Exhibit C.
John McAnyone: I have the craziest story--last night I had 5 beers and started dancing on top of...

Storytopper: You think that’s crazy? Well, I’ll tell you something crazy--the other night I had 9 beers and then...

If these examples seem exaggerated, I assure you, they only depart from verbatim conversation enough to disguise the identity of the storytoppers involved.

I wish our self-obsession was less obvious, less transparent, less contrived, but, as it stands, it’s pretty ugly. It's stark and small and it would be funnier if it weren't so pathetic.

Paul, very patiently, tells early Christians "Don’t think you are better than you really are" (Romans 12:3). It's a statement so simple it seems unnecessary.

Storytoppers, we need to stop.

Next time you see me flaunting a little one-upmanship, you better call me out. Believe me, I'll be doing the same.

Sam

data.title: Marriage is Insane
data.content:
Marriage might just be the most insanely difficult task a person can take on.

The knowing of someone and that someone's knowing of yourself is incredibly vulnerable. The journey is inevitably riddled with defensive spasms, long sieges against internal fortresses you never knew existed and sometimes, let's face it, an aching sense of dissatisfaction.

I think the idea that only half of marriages fail is naively optimistic. Include all the sexless marriages, the cold, the indifferent, the bitter and the emotionally abusive marriages and the remainder thins to a sliver.

It's not that marriage is to blame. Any authentic relationship including family, dating relationships and close friendships suffer from the same struggles. But with marriage, you're stuck. There's no leaving for college, there's no "I've just been too busy to hang out lately" or "let's just take a step back" when things get messy.

People are all smashed up. Though we were made to function as this beautiful, holistic community, our brokenness has driven us so far apart that it's hard to even imagine what God originally intended when he said, "It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper who is just right for him" (Genesis 2:18).

Marriage is the slow deconstruction and reassembling of two human beings who were made to fit together but don't even come close any more. My old wounds have to be unwrapped. Her bullets have to be removed. Our anger, our bitterness, our addictions, our judgmental hearts and lies have to be drawn out into the open, understood and disassembled.

It's no wonder that failure is the rule. But if the central goal for humankind is to be reconciled to God and to each other (and it is [2 Corinthians 5:18]), then marriage is important not only for me and Kate, but for our friends, our family, and humanity as a whole. All told, more damage may be done than good within marriages, but the potential for healing--for true, lasting healing--is more potent than I could ever have imagined. It's awe-inspiring.

"And the two will become one flesh" (Ephesians. 5:31).

Sam

data.title: The Perils of Driving with a Missing Tail Light
data.content:
A pair of police lights spiraled in the rearview mirror.

Kate pulled over, and in the passenger seat, Stephanie buckled her seatbelt. In the back, my roommate and I wiped the smiles off our faces, did our best to look like polite young men. The officer walked towards us, flashlight in hand. Kate rolled down the window, he poked his head in, and the mood instantly went from tense to...something else.

He was perfect. Even from the backseat I could tell that. Muscular, tan, broad-shouldered, with a firm jaw ever-so-slightly stubbled. He peered through the open window into the car with a charming, confident smile.

"Pardon me, ladies," he said, tipping his cap to them with nary a look at us two guys in the backseat. "Just thought you should know you have a tail light out."

Kate and Stephanie couldn't seem to find words kind enough to express their full gratitude.

And, in that moment, I desperately wanted something to be wrong with that cop. I wanted him to be financially unlucky, a slow reader, stupid tattoos--anything. I had to imagine superiority in some area. "Anger is cruel and wrath is like a flood," says Proverbs 27:4, "but jealousy is even more dangerous." Dangerous, perhaps, because of its subtle strength. One minute, you're noticing the expensive car or gorgeous wife. The next, there's a burning mess of ill-will in your brain, all because someone else is better.

Maybe that's all jealousy is. The feeling we get whenever our superiority is threatened.

The cop left, and Kate rolled up her window. "He was," Stephanie paused, looking for the right word. "Good-looking," she finally finished with upraised eyebrows.

We walk through life with understood areas of control, little domains in which we are chief. We guard them with our egos, and only surrender them bitterly. We feel jealous only because we want to be better. And maybe we could stave off this rage, this bitterest of stains, with only a little more thought to Jesus' most famous words.

"God blesses those who are humble, for they will inherit the whole earth" (Matthew 5:5).

Joe

data.title: Marie
data.content:
I never really understood giving your shirt to the man who steals your coat. Or if I'm truly supposed to offer up my other cheek to an angry backhand. Every time I read these kinds of verses, I think of people who need or ask for my help. I think of people with hats on the cement platforms in subways. I don't think about Marie.

In Luke 6, Jesus says: "...love your enemies! Do good to those who hate you. Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who hurt you. If someone slaps you on one cheek...."

Enemies. Someone who wants me to fail. Somebody I want to fail. Or even, someone who thinks I feel that way about them. Everybody has an enemy.

Friends told me to, "Live and let live." That Marie and I just weren't friends anymore. She scolded me. Ignored me. Holds grudges against me. There's nothing I can do about it. All these things are true. Except that:

"If you love only those who love you, why should you get credit for that? Even sinners love those who love them! And if you do good only to those who do good to you, why should you get credit? Even sinners do that much!" (Luke 6:32-33).

I bought Marie a small gift. I'm mailing it to her with a very short note, "Made me think of you. Hope you're doing well." I'm not going to call her or send her a message on Facebook. But I'm also not going to, "Live and let live." I will love. And love is a choice. Love is pro-active. Love always moves.

Our pastor asked us, "Do you want to test the strength of your love? Then love without getting anything back for it."

"Love your enemies! Do good to them. Lend to them without expecting to be repaid. Then your reward from heaven will be very great, and you will truly be acting as children of the Most High, for he is kind to those who are unthankful and wicked" (Luke 6:35).

Like me.

June

data.title: Like Some Thief
data.content:
When I moved to Pittsburgh, I was warned of all sorts of things that ranged from which roads to avoid during rush hour to the alluring deliciousness of perogies.

"She's dramatic," I was told about one of the girls I would be living with, "the guys hate her." The lighthearted laughter which accompanied the story made it sound like these were actually quite endearing traits. "Just uh...I wouldn't trust her with any...important information. She's a great girl. But not that good at keeping things to herself."

The irony struck me at the time. That someone would ruin their reputation with their loose tongue. And that I would learn about it basically the same way.

Most of the time gossip just seems petty. To spread it and to let it bother you. Like having a taste for potato chips or crying at a two-year-old's sloshy punch in the chest.

But gossip isn't petty.

It shows up right alongside things like murder, envy, and greed as Paul lists things that "should never be done" (Romans 1:28). Later, James gives us a pretty jolting picture of our tongues. "It can set your whole life on fire. For it is set on fire by hell itself" (3:6).

Jeez.

Chances are, we won't see the effects of gossip like a burning flame from hell in our living rooms. In fact, we might barely notice. But. Like some stealthy, sneaky, greasy-haired thief, this way of things will steal from us. From how much people trust us. From how we see other people. From the health of our friendships.

My roommate is terribly sweet, generous and funny. And I still sometimes think of her as the girl I can't trust.

Makes me want to take care with my petty words.

Em

data.title: Loss
data.content:
If I were ruler of the world, trying to think of some way to respond to my people's rebellion, to wake them up to reality, I don't think I could conjure up a more devastating punishment than death.

Being ripped away--like a child from its mother--is horrifying. To think about one day being severed from someone you've known intimately during every poolside barbeque and thanksgiving dinner... I shudder. You see their empty spot at the table or a picture framed from another year, and you can barely believe that from here on out there will be no more memories.

I lost my mom a year before I graduated high school. And since then, the overwhelming reality of how short life is weighs on me. At my high school graduation I thought, she's not here. My college graduation. My engagement. My wedding. She's not here. And I will eventually lose my father...then probably my step-mom...or my in-laws...possibly a sibling...then my friends.

And thus, one by one, begins the slow and disrupting downward spiral of loss.

In Romans 5, Paul contrasts Adam and Jesus in relation to their effect on humanity. He says, "For the sin of this one man, Adam, caused death to rule over many. But even greater is God's wonderful grace and his gift of righteousness, for all who receive it will live in triumph over sin and death through this one man, Jesus Christ."

God isn't barbaric for putting this punishment on us. He didn't think of it just to make us experience greater pain. He actually created us to never even know death. Sin brought funerals and cancers.

But as inescapable as this plague that cuts our breaths in half...as persistent as the nagging shadow that follows us through every triumph and sunny day. As wide and as all-encompassing as death is...as threatening and as powerful--so is the saving plan of God. Just as much.

And so much more.
June

data.title: Love
data.content:
I behaved horribly at my sister's wedding.

I was angry; she's nineteen, I didn't know the guy, I wanted her to leave our small town for at least a little while, to test herself and even her faith in God on the hard material of the world.

There is a series of photographs in our family albums that documents a time she went through in which she tried to copy everything I did. She'd follow me anywhere, into anything, and even later, when I came home from whatever half-hearted soul journey I was on, she'd listen to me like I knew what I was talking about.

I wanted to shoot her fiancé. I hated the surety of his movements with her. Everything felt wrong. I knew I could do nothing, short of murder, to change the course of her wedding.

And so I had to watch like some chained dog as Dad gave her away. She looked so young coming down the aisle. Young and beautiful and full of goodness.

I wanted to tell her that for once I really did know what was best, for once I wasn't the one making the mistake. I wanted to tell her I loved her more truly than I loved anyone or anything else in this world.

Then they were on the altar, and taking the vows, and the pastor read from 1 Corinthians.

"Love is patient and kind; love does not envy or boast; it is not arrogant or rude. It does not insist on its own way; it is not irritable or resentful" (13:4-5).

And in the midst of my self-righteous anger, I thought: What do I know of love, anyway?

Simply put, I ran head first, again, into the love that should be in my life and is not. Head first into how badly I want to love and how badly I fall short. Almost every time I fail, I think that this is the last time. I think: I'm done. But I'm not, I'm not done, and there is, somewhere in me, an indomitable spirit that most of all desires goodness, and to learn to love.

"Yes, I am the vine; you are the branches. Those who remain in me, and I in them, will produce much fruit. For apart from me you can do nothing" (John 14:5).

Silas

data.title: Turning Anger Down
data.content:
I did something the other day that felt like magic. I've been trying to practice Proverbs 15:1 in my real life. Okay, with my boss. It says, "A gentle answer deflects anger, but harsh words make tempers flare."

See, my boss's management style is what you would call "motivation by yelling." He's a yeller. He can be an angry guy, and you can see it coming. When that little vein on the side of his head starts doing a jig, the explosion is imminent.

My wife suggested I try out this verse. I'll be honest. I didn't give it much of a shot. I mean, I believe the Bible is true. I just wasn't sure it applied to people like my boss.

So I'm late on a project. Unavoidable. My boss is actually the one who put me on something else, forgot about it, and then demanded to know where the first job was. Classic.

As I was explaining, I noticed that little vein on his head doing its thing and, sure enough, the tirade began. My wife must have been praying, because I didn't yell back or slap him with a sarcastic remark. (My usual tactic.) Instead I quietly said, "I can see you're upset about this; what can I do to help make it right?"

Whoa! It was like watching a pit bull turn into a poodle. His anger vanished, and he couldn't quite look me in the eye. He stammered a little and said something about looking at the schedule together later.

I don't know if it's because he was expecting a fight or just because I made it about him and what he needed. But it worked. I can't say it was as satisfying as yelling back at him, but it was definitely more productive. And a little magic.

Might be something to these proverbs.

Hank

data.title: Unexpected
data.content:
The concert ran late, and my friend, Brendan, and I still have an hour's drive ahead. We need some gas and caffeine.

"Keiffer!?"

Huh? Who's calling me in the darkness of a frigid night at a deserted gas station in a huge city where I don't live?

It's her.

I haven't seen her since. Haven't spoken a word. Don't want to. The last words my wife and I heard were lies straight to our faces, but that was nothing. We were merely second parties, bystanders. It was my brother she betrayed: lying, cheating, diving in wholeheartedly to an affair and torching her marriage without a glance backward.

How many hours had I listened and comforted and cried with my brother as his heart and life were gutted? How much shock had we endured as she lived out soap opera plots?

So that stuff does happen in real life.

I would never begin to suggest my hurt or betrayal came within miles of my brother's. My anger was a protective, defensive one for my closest friend and blood relative. I'd have given anything to shield him from the emotional torture.

Now she's calling out of the cold under fluorescent gas station lights like a friend from years past--which she was, and more. She was family...before.

It feels surreal trying to make small talk and not wanting to. What do you say? Hey, haven't seen you since you started having sex with that other married man. How's that working out for you?

Processing my encounter later I realized how mad I still was. But I'd watched my brother reach true forgiveness as God put him back together through several painful years. If he could forgive her, how could I not?

That night I started to see her as human again, broken and battered from her own choices and actions. She's more than her mistakes--just like I hope I am. I don't have to like what she did, but I have to choose to leave it between her and God.

"Then Peter came to him and asked, "Lord, how often should I forgive someone who sins against me? Seven times?" "No, not seven times," Jesus replied, "but seventy times seven!" (Matthew 18:21-22).

Keiffer

data.title: It Was Given
data.content:
The Malabar Whistling Thrush is a bird native to India that sings at day break. Its song sounds just like a man's contemplative whistle. I heard it very early one morning in India, when I thought I was alone.

Yesterday, I found a two-minute sound clip (play audio above) of the India jungle as it wakes in the morning. The sheer diversity of the bird calls is dumbfounding. There are a hundred unique threads being woven, from the liquid bright calls of the small birds to the harsher caws of the red-winged black bird, and yet all together they sound beautiful; a complex tapestry sewn in the air each morning.

My dad always says, excitedly, as he shows me an amethyst crystal or an agate, "It doesn't have to be like this." And he says it when he talks about the stars up at the cabin.

In the first chapter of Brennan Manning's The Ragamuffin Gospel, he talks about the problem with the American idea of worthiness. Sayings like, "You get what you pay for" showcase a philosophy that has no room for mercy or for grace. He also had me thinking about what my dad says as he steps out the door in the morning: "It doesn't have to be like this."

"For God has saved us and called us to a holy life. He did this, not because we deserved it, but because that was his plan from before the beginning of time--to show us his grace through Christ Jesus" (2 Timothy 1:9).

It doesn't have to be beautiful, but it is. And none of us does anything to earn the beauty that is poured down on us from summer skies.

There's something to be learned about grace there, something to be learned about an ancient Kingdom in the unnecessary beauty of the bird songs in India.

Silas

data.title: Cowboy Up
data.content:
I don't hate chick flicks. I'll watch a romantic comedy with my wife. Some of them are kind of funny and it can create a nice mood for an evening together. I enjoy a good kids' movie, too, especially if it makes my five-year-old laugh or gets his imagination rolling.

But if I'm looking for a movie just for me, I'll skip those two genres. I want something with some meat, something challenging, something with big ideas--or big explosions. It's honestly not about swearing, sex, and violence, just something that's a little tougher than Pixar or Sandra Bullock.

That's why I like Hebrews 12 so much. Sometimes church can feel like it's built for the Women and Kids demographic, with all of the emphasis on feelings and relationships and simplified Bible stories.

But Hebrews 12 is tough. It says God expects me to do hard things: You've got a mission. Ditch anything that slows you down--and keep going.

By the way, it says, God's going to discipline me like a good Father. He's going to bring some hardship my way to keep my head in the game, to make me stronger, to make me want to shake loose of sin. I might bleed.

Don't take it as betrayal, man, take it as love.

Then this in verses 12-13, after the discipline: "So take a new grip with your tired hands and strengthen your weak knees. Mark out a straight path for your feet so that those who are weak and lame will not fall but become strong."

Yeah, you're tired, but you're not done, yet. Keep going. It matters. And he's given you everything you need to get the job done.

I dig the idea that God wants me to cowboy up. It makes me want to give him all I've got, to not hold anything back. It makes me want to be a man.

Read the chapter. You'll see what I mean.

Hank

data.title: Bitter Stew
data.content:
I was just reading through 1 Corinthians 13 as it applies to my marriage and got convicted about another love relationship in my life.

My sister stopped speaking to me about 8 months ago. We disagree about a lot of things philosophically, politically and spiritually but have always managed to not let those disagreements get in the way of our relationship. Last year, though, she took a stand over a political issue. She wanted me to contribute money to an organization that she supports but that I feel goes against some of God's most basic principles. When I said "no", she flew off the handle and cut me out of her life.

At first I was sad and sympathetic. As time went on, though, I got mad and then progressed to bitter and now have comfortably settled into a simmering mess of self-righteous anger and unforgiving pouting. It's not a good place to be and I know this, but I've drawn my hurt around me like a blanket and here I sit. At this point, I don't know how I would react if she approached me. Not well, I'm afraid.

I know better. I really, really do. But I can't seem to help myself. This morning, though, I read "Love never gives up, never loses faith, is always hopeful, and endures through every circumstance." That does not describe me or my feelings about my sister whom I say I love.

Also, "When I was a child, I spoke and thought and reasoned as a child. But when I grew up, I put away childish things" (1 Corinthians 13:11). If sitting in a simmering stew of pouting bitterness is not childish, I don't know what is. It's time to grow up.

Darn it. I hate this. I hate that I have to give up these feelings that I think I'm entitled to. I hate that I'm going to have to pray long and hard and ask God to help me forgive and behave lovingly. I don't know why I want to hang on to my hard heart so much, but I do.

Trying to get over myself,
Jennifer

data.title: Letting It Go for Real
data.content:
Do you ever catch yourself in a moment where everything seems to slow down and all of your choices become very clear, very black and white? It happened to me again the other night.

I was talking to my wife. We'd both been edgy all day, and we were on each other about money stuff again. (Why is it always money stuff?) Anyway, she said something to me that stung (because it was true), and I immediately thought of the perfectly hurtful retort to sting her back.

But what I thought of to say had to do with something I'd forgiven her for months ago. She had said those three magic words back then: "I was wrong." I said those other three magic words: "I forgive you."

Now I was reaching back to that thing I had supposedly let go to slap her with it. I knew it was wrong in the instant before I said it anyway. I knew it even better by the hurt look on her face. (I hate that look.)

Either I had not really forgiven her or I just knew that opening that old wound would make for a good weapon in an ugly moment. Not a Christ-like moment in either case.

I knew it better still when I read these words from Proverbs 17:9 later, "Love prospers when a fault is forgiven, but dwelling on it separates close friends."

It was my turn to say the three magic words and her turn to say the other three back to me. And, knowing her, she won't bring it up again. She's way better at making love prosper than I usually am.

But I'm trying. No more dwelling on the forgiven things. No more using them for ammo.

At least not today.

Hank

data.title: Sharp Objects
data.content:
In 1 Samuel 22, Saul lashes out at his officers in a paranoid panic. He accuses them of aiding David by concealing information from him. One of Saul's lead officers, Doeg, says he saw the priest Ahimelech feeding David and praying for him. Saul sends for Ahimelech and his fellow priests:

"'Why have you and the son of Jesse conspired against me?'...

'Why did you give him food and a sword? Why have you consulted God for him? Why have you encouraged him to kill me, as he is trying to do this very day?'"

Ahimelech respectfully defends David's loyalty and assures Saul there is no plot on his life.

So Saul kills him. Ahimelech and the eighty-four priests with him, all still in their priestly garments--dead. Then Doeg goes into the priests' hometown and slaughters all their men, women, children and babies.

When I first read this, I was appalled. But it scares me how much I see of myself in this story. I remember the unsteadiness I feel when giving solace to my prejudices. I like to say I'm standing for justice, that I'm only upset because of sin. But there's a reason God tells us to leave justice up to him. It's like all those other stories of people consumed by their revenge or their greed--they never know peace. But this isn't the lot of a person who's surrendered to God.

In the beginning of the story, Saul is sitting under a tree, surrounded by his military--holding his spear. Sometimes I feel like that's what I'm doing. Tempting my mind with sharp words and accusations against others. Thinking I can dwell on these things while remaining devoted to God. I don't realize how easily those thoughts can cut into my veins. That I'm really not that far away from being like Saul.

"If you think you are standing strong, be careful not to fall. The temptations in your life are no different from what others experience. And God is faithful...When you are tempted, he will show you a way out so that you can endure" (1 Corinthians 10).

I guess the question is more like: Do I want a way out?

June

data.title: Free to Love Freely
data.content:
"Don't get in the habit of thinking the worst of people." Somebody said that to me last week. Honestly, I was a bit jolted. Hardly ever do people tell you things without mincing their words. Hardly ever do people favor truth to laziness.

I could see the pattern in myself. Cynicism. Aloofness. Roadblocks of self-defense. Sabotage mechanisms lest anyone perceive me as weak, lest anyone dare to take advantage. Preempting the possibility of being hurt or disappointed.

What a terrible way to live.

Abe Lincoln once said that the surest way to feel secure that your house would not be robbed was to be sure never to rob anyone else.

I like this because of two things: 1. It highlights our unavoidable vulnerability. In the end, people can hurt us and lie to us and take advantage of us. They just can and they probably will. 2. It reminds us that we still have a choice in how we're going to live and how we're going to feel while we live.

You might as well.

You might as well be a person who believes people, who loves people, who gives to people. You might as well laugh hard and greet your friends with enthusiasm. You might as well be a little too eager. A little too forgiving. A little too.

Why isn't it pure insanity to live with grace, grace, grace and love, love, love? Because we have been given permission to die to ourselves. I say it like this because it is a very liberating thing, to be able to hold your own interests at arm's length, in favor of loving the people around you. You are. I am. We can be free to love freely.

"'...love the LORD your God with all your heart, all your soul, all your mind, and all your strength.... Love your neighbor as yourself. No other commandment is greater than these'" (Mark 12:30-31).

Em

data.title: Easy Love
data.content:
The other night, we all decided to eat at Chipotle for dinner. Three other girls and me. Problem was, three of us were together, but Emily was driving in from work. I was, apparently, in charge of coordinating all of our schedules.

In hindsight, this was probably where the problems began. Emily ended up getting crazy frustrated with me because I couldn't remember to call her every time the plans changed. I wish I could explain the whole situation, but I'm not trying to vent here. Suffice it to say, she was a little annoyed with me and I with her.

Then, two days later, I said to my husband, "Want to go over to Bryce and Emily's?" I was excited. I wanted to see them. I'd forgotten that the last time I saw Emily we were avoiding eye contact. As we were driving over to their house, I suddenly remembered. And I got fiery. All I can think about was how unreasonable and unfair she was. How much she hurt my feelings.

There's this pithy saying in Romans 12 that I've always found particularly witty and yet surprisingly unhelpful: "Don't just pretend to love others. Really love them" (12:9).

It's followed by some verses that I never really understood the connection to before now.

"Love each other with genuine affection, and take delight in honoring each other.
...Be patient in trouble, and keep on praying.
...Live in harmony with each other... And don't think you know it all!
Never pay back evil with more evil... Do all that you can to live in peace with everyone.
...Don't let evil conquer you, but conquer evil by doing good."

I'd like to say that when I got to Emily's, I kept my mouth shut. But I didn't. I tried to explain the Chipotle disaster to her. She only repeated her frustrated sentiments from two nights before. I sighed at her a little bit, as I'm sure she did at me. And then we happily moved on. Because some things just aren't worth fighting over.

June

data.title: Mistakes
data.content:
My good friend Anne is a self-professed control freak. I don't mean she's obnoxiously clean or tidy--she wants to control people. We used to talk a lot about when we would have kids; Anne just had her first a few months ago. I always said my biggest fear was making the wrong decisions or punishing them inappropriately. Anne said she was most afraid of their sin.

She was afraid she'd spend all these years raising and teaching her kids, only to have them attach themselves to something destructive. It still scares her to this day. And I don't blame her. We want our loved ones, especially our children, to be protected from all the things that hurt us. We don't want them making the same mistakes.

Maybe this is what bothered me so much the other day, when I read David's Song of Deliverance:

"For I have kept the ways of the Lord;
I have not turned from my God to follow evil.
I have followed all his regulations;
I have never abandoned his decrees.
I am blameless before God;
I have kept myself from sin" (2 Samuel 22:22-24).

What is he talking about!? Who can honestly say those things? And David of all people! It seemed so bold and naive. Here I was, thinking about how to overcome my anxiety about hurting the people I love most, and there's David, saying he's awesome. Saying things I knew weren't true.

"To the faithful you show yourself faithful;
to those with integrity you show integrity.
To the pure you show yourself pure" (Psalm 18:25-26)

I fought with this in my head for a while. I even fought about it with my husband. God changed David's heart. He was a new man. And here he praises God for that. David isn't being arrogant or naive. He knows he messed up. But he also knew that God was just. And that a pure heart would not go unnoticed.

We can't protect the people we love. We can't stop them from making our mistakes. But we can teach them how to deal with those mistakes. We can show them what it looks like to be someone who knows when they're wrong. Maybe being a mature Christian has more to do with thanking God for helping us grow, in spite of ourselves.

June

data.title: Hi. My Name is Joe and I'm Addicted to Others.
data.content:
I do anything to avoid being alone.

We're talking extreme measures. I blitz my friends' phones with calls and texts. I show up at their front doors. If all else fails, I just go to my neighborhood coffee shop or something, where there's bound to be some sort of friend. It makes me a bit of a pest, but it beats the alternative.

It's because when I'm alone, I have to talk to myself. And the things that my "self" reveals to "me" are very unpleasant. I realize that I see myself as sort of a reject, with more F's on my report card than A's. I'm bitter, a little angry, and doubt a lot of things about myself, God, and life.

So, I run from being alone. I go out every night and, frankly, can be the life of the party. An outsider who looks at my life probably says, "That guy, Joe, he's so popular." And they're right, in a way--but I only have a lot of friends because I'm so lonely.

It's true, I'm addicted to others.

It's a story we're familiar with. I hear it from pastors all the time: "No one can fill the void in your soul, except for Jesus!" I read it in Mark 8:36, "And what do you benefit if you gain the whole world but lose your own soul?" But, here's the simple truth: I'm generally trying to hang onto my soul while still gaining the whole world. I'm shuffling around my soul's furniture to make room for Jesus plus whoever else can be squeezed in.

But the thing is, when Jesus can get me alone--lonely, insecure, scared, hurt, and angry--it's when he has me there that we're really getting somewhere. Because if his 'power works best in weakness' (2 Corinthians 12:9), then there's something to be said for seeking out loneliness. It's when I'm alone that I really need him--and maybe that's why I run from it.

Trying to stand still,
Joe

data.content:

data.title: What God Won't Forget
data.content:
When you were a kid, did you ever have that experience at a store when you turn around from looking at something and your parents are nowhere to be seen? It’s terrifying! There was a time in Israel's history when they "turned around" and thought God had left them behind. Isaiah the prophet reassured them:

Isaiah 49:13-15

Sing for joy, O heavens!
Rejoice, O earth!
Burst into song, O mountains!
For the LORD has comforted his people
and will have compassion on them in their suffering.

Yet Jerusalem says, "The LORD has deserted us;
the Lord has forgotten us."

"Never! Can a mother forget her nursing child?
Can she feel no love for the child she has borne?
But even if that were possible,
I would not forget you!"

Sadly, humans are different. There are far too many people out there who have been abandoned. But if that's you, remember, God will never leave you. Ever.

data.title: Lazybones
data.content:
Lazy people get no props in the Bible. We're not talking about people who cannot work for one reason or another, but those who can. They have the ability and the opportunity to work, and instead choose to watch life pass them by.

Some translations call them a sluggard, and this one calls them "lazybones."

Proverbs 6:9-11

But you, lazybones, how long will you sleep?
When will you wake up?
A little extra sleep, a little more slumber,
a little folding of the hands to rest--
then poverty will pounce on you like a bandit;
scarcity will attack you like an armed robber.

In short: Don't be lazy! If you sit around doing nothing all day, go figure that you have very little going on in your life. Write that book, go meet those friends, get that job, sing that song, and love your God. Don't let your lazy bones bring you down.

data.title: Lions and Bears!
data.content:
Get this: armed with a club, David killed both lions and bears. You know, I bet he wondered why God allowed these beasts to attack his sheep 24/7.

1 Samuel 17:33-37

"Don't be ridiculous!" Saul replied. "There's no way you can fight this Philistine and possibly win! You're only a boy, and he's been a man of war since his youth."

But David persisted. "I have been taking care of my father's sheep and goats," he said. "When a lion or a bear comes to steal a lamb from the flock, I go after it with a club and rescue the lamb from its mouth. If the animal turns on me, I catch it by the jaw and club it to death. I have done this to both lions and bears, and I'll do it to this pagan Philistine, too, for he has defied the armies of the living God! The LORD who rescued me from the claws of the lion and the bear will rescue me from this Philistine!"

Perhaps the lions and bears of your life are preparing you to chase bigger obstacles with brave certainty. You like that metaphor?! You know what I'm saying though--God knows what's coming and he's getting you ready.

data.title: The Blame Game
data.content:
The blame game--we're all guilty of it. You ever questioned its roots? Well, I'm not pointing fingers, but...

Genesis 3:6,9-13

The woman was convinced. She saw that the tree was beautiful and its fruit looked delicious, and she wanted the wisdom it would give her. So she took some of the fruit and ate it. Then she gave some to her husband, who was with her, and he ate it, too.

Then the Lord God called to the man, "Where are you?"

He replied, "I heard you walking in the garden, so I hid. I was afraid because I was naked."

"Who told you that you were naked?" the Lord God asked. "Have you eaten from the tree whose fruit I commanded you not to eat?"

The man replied, "It was the woman you gave me who gave me the fruit, and I ate it."

Then the Lord God asked the woman, "What have you done?"

"The serpent deceived me," she replied. "That's why I ate it."

We are responsible for our own actions. Adam and Eve opened the door to sin, but all of us walk through it.

data.content:
Hey, it's goTandem with a familiar story found in

"Then the King will say to those on his right, 'Come, you who are blessed by my Father, inherit the Kingdom prepared for you from the creation of the world. For I was hungry, and you fed me. I was thirsty, and you gave me a drink.'"

...

"Then these righteous ones will reply, 'Lord, when did we ever see you hungry and feed you? Or thirsty and give you something to drink?

...

"And the King will say, 'I tell you the truth, when you did it to one of the least of these my brothers and sisters, you were doing it to me!'"

I love that these people were surprised that God had noticed their actions. It means they genuinely cared for the people they were helping. They weren't trying to get brownie points with God or earn any favors. They just wanted to help.

data.title: Life on Jesus' Terms
data.content:
You know, it's easy to get the impression that Jesus came to give us a life of pleasure and peace on our own terms. That's why verses like this, where Jesus insists we live life on his terms, are so jarring.

Matthew 10:37-39

"If you love your father or mother more than you love me, you are not worthy of being mine; or if you love your son or daughter more than me, you are not worthy of being mine. If you refuse to take up your cross and follow me, you are not worthy of being mine. If you cling to your life, you will lose it; but if you give up your life for me, you will find it."

Now, be careful. Jesus isn't telling us to hate our parents or our children here. He's asking us to trust him to love them more than we ever could. If our devotion to our family gets in the way of our devotion to God, then, yes, it's a problem, because we can not only get in the way of the plan God has for our lives, but the plan he has for those we love too.

data.title: The Courage of a Desk
data.content:
When you think of courage, you probably don't think of a desk. But have you ever had one of those days where the last thing you want to do is to work? Then listen to this from

1 Chronicles 28:20

Then David continued, "Be strong and courageous, and do the work. Don't be afraid or discouraged, for the LORD God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or forsake you. He will see to it that all the work related to the Temple of the LORD is finished correctly."

Sometimes the most courageous thing you can do is to lower your head and accomplish whatever task is set before you, whether it's doing your homework, filling out your taxes, or playing with your kids after a really long day on the job. Whatever it is...be strong. Be courageous. And do the work.

data.title: Answer ME!
data.content:
David was in a horrible place when he wrote Psalm 38. Feeling tired, alone, and like the world was against him, as a lot of us often do. He prayed these words to God.

Psalm 38:9-15

You know what I long for, Lord;
you hear my every sigh.
My heart beats wildly, my strength fails,
and I am going blind.
My loved ones and friends stay away, fearing my disease.
Even my own family stands at a distance.
Meanwhile, my enemies lay traps to kill me.
Those who wish me harm make plans to ruin me.
All day long they plan their treachery.

But I am deaf to all their threats.
I am silent before them as one who cannot speak.
I choose to hear nothing,
and I make no reply.
For I am waiting for you, O LORD.
You must answer for me, O Lord my God.

Prayer--that's something we can't do wrong. God always wants to hear from us.
