data.title: Being Golden
data.content:
Man, it's so easy to get mad at someone right? I'm guilty of this! Ok, here's what Jesus had to say.

Luke 6:27-31

"But to you who are willing to listen, I say, love your enemies! Do good to those who hate you. Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who hurt you. If someone slaps you on one cheek, offer the other cheek also. If someone demands your coat, offer your shirt also. Give to anyone who asks; and when things are taken away from you, don't try to get them back. Do to others as you would like them to do to you."

That's the Golden Rule. You've known it since you were like four. It's so simple, yet so hard. Look, it starts with you. Brutal right?! Yeah, but you can apply this in some way.

data.title: Understanding Loneliness
data.content:
When everything is so bad you start feeling alone, who could possibly comprehend what you're going through? Well, there's at least one person who gets it.

Isaiah 53:3-6

He was despised and rejected--
a man of sorrows, acquainted with deepest grief.
We turned our backs on him and looked the other way.
He was despised, and we did not care.

Yet it was our weaknesses he carried;
it was our sorrows that weighed him down.
And we thought his troubles were a punishment from God,
a punishment for his own sins!
But he was pierced for our rebellion,
crushed for our sins.
He was beaten so we could be whole.
He was whipped so we could be healed.
All of us, like sheep, have strayed away.
We have left God's paths to follow our own.
Yet the LORD laid on him
the sins of us all.

Not only does Jesus understand, but he carried your weakness and sorrow to the cross--he died for it. It doesn't always make it feel all right, but it's hope.

data.title: Is More Better?
data.content:
No blame game here, but, we're hit with thousands of ads a day telling us we need stuff. According to daily marketing, you can never have enough, right?

Ecclesiastes 5:10-11

Those who love money will never have enough. How meaningless to think that wealth brings true happiness! The more you have, the more people come to help you spend it. So what good is wealth--except perhaps to watch it slip through your fingers!

1 Timothy 6:6-8

Yet true godliness with contentment is itself great wealth. After all, we brought nothing with us when we came into the world, and we can't take anything with us when we leave it. So if we have enough food and clothing, let us be content.

Philippians 4:11

Not that I was ever in need, for I have learned how to be content with whatever I have.

Just a little perspective.

data.title: Easy to See
data.content:
In video games, your objective is always easy to figure out: there's one path to walk through the room; there's an arrow pointing to the guy to talk to; there are space invaders coming and you have the gun. Wouldn't it be nice if the people God wanted us to help were just as easy to see?

Matthew 25:44-45

"Then they will reply, 'Lord, when did we ever see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and not help you?'

"And he will answer, 'I tell you the truth, when you refused to help the least of these my brothers and sisters, you were refusing to help me.'"

You know, there are people we're around every day that we can help. We just have to pay attention.

data.title: Centering Tips
data.content:
You know, there are a lot of things that try to take our attention off of God. Here are some tips on how to keep God right at the center of your life.

Psalm 101:2-5

I will be careful to live a blameless life--
when will you come to help me?
I will lead a life of integrity
in my own home.
I will refuse to look at
anything vile and vulgar.
I hate all who deal crookedly;
I will have nothing to do with them.
I will reject perverse ideas
and stay away from every evil.
I will not tolerate people who slander their neighbors.
I will not endure conceit and pride.

Did you notice that every verse starts with, "I will"? So, what will you do today?

data.title: Assignments
data.content:
Have you ever been given an assignment? Like, your boss comes to you and says, "I'm going to be gone for the afternoon. While I'm gone, I need you to make 50 copies of the Daniel's Report, and buy me a case of Sprite for my little refrigerator."

This is sort of what Jesus did. He died on the cross, rose from the dead, and then ascended to heaven. But before he left, he gave us an assignment.

Matthew 28:16-20

Then the eleven disciples left for Galilee, going to the mountain where Jesus had told them to go. When they saw him, they worshiped him--but some of them doubted!

Jesus came and told his disciples, "I have been given all authority in heaven and on earth. Therefore, go and make disciples of all the nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit. Teach these new disciples to obey all the commands I have given you. And be sure of this: I am with you always, even to the end of the age."

So his assignment: Make disciples. He told this to his disciples, "Hey disciples, go do what I did, but with other people." And you may be listening to this as a current disciple of Jesus because those guys did their job way back in the day. And so it continues. The task falls to you. Who are you discipling right now?

data.title: Suffering is...Special?
data.content:
Paul tells us that there is something special in suffering.

2 Corinthians 12:6-10

If I wanted to boast, I would be no fool in doing so, because I would be telling the truth. But I won't do it, because I don't want anyone to give me credit beyond what they can see in my life or hear in my message, even though I have received such wonderful revelations from God. So to keep me from becoming proud, I was given a thorn in my flesh, a messenger from Satan to torment me and keep me from becoming proud.

Three different times I begged the Lord to take it away. Each time he said, "My grace is all you need. My power works best in weakness." So now I am glad to boast about my weaknesses, so that the power of Christ can work through me. That's why I take pleasure in my weaknesses, and in the insults, hardships, persecutions, and troubles that I suffer for Christ. For when I am weak, then I am strong.

What are you going through? Look for ways to allow God's power to shine through. We know it's hard, but look for God's grace in it.

data.title: Do Your Duty
data.content:
Here's what Paul had to say to Timothy about staying strong in his calling.

2 Timothy 4:1-5

I solemnly urge you in the presence of God and Christ Jesus, who will someday judge the living and the dead when he appears to set up his Kingdom: Preach the word of God. Be prepared, whether the time is favorable or not. Patiently correct, rebuke, and encourage your people with good teaching.

For a time is coming when people will no longer listen to sound and wholesome teaching. They will follow their own desires and will look for teachers who will tell them whatever their itching ears want to hear. They will reject the truth and chase after myths.

But you should keep a clear mind in every situation. Don't be afraid of suffering for the Lord. Work at telling others the Good News, and fully carry out the ministry God has given you.

Ok, if you had to stand before Jesus at the end of today, what would you do between now and then?

data.title: Flavor of the Month
data.content:
Evil comes in a lot of flavors--like ice cream. Well, like bad ice cream that ultimately makes you sick and separates you from God. Everything from murder to hatred, promiscuity to lust, oppressing the poor to simply hoarding and consuming more than you need are all forms of what the Bible would label 'evil.' Paul wrote this:

1 Thessalonians 5:22-24

Stay away from every kind of evil.

Now may the God of peace make you holy in every way, and may your whole spirit and soul and body be kept blameless until our Lord Jesus Christ comes again. God will make this happen, for he who calls you is faithful.

Blameless. Different. Holy. Is that how people would describe you? God will make it happen. He is faithful. May you keep yourself from evil and walk in his ways.

data.title: Jolt
data.content:
Thought you might need a little jolt of wisdom today. Wisdom is founded on the concept that you don't have to experience everything personally to learn it. A collection of wisdom sayings known as the Book of Proverbs has this to say about patience, jealousy, helping the poor, and being godly:

Proverbs 14:29-33

People with understanding control their anger;
a hot temper shows great foolishness.

A peaceful heart leads to a healthy body;
jealousy is like cancer in the bones.

Those who oppress the poor insult their Maker,
but helping the poor honors him.

The wicked are crushed by disaster,
but the godly have a refuge when they die.

Wisdom is enshrined in an understanding heart;
wisdom is not found among fools.

So take this wisdom jolt and use it. Don't be a fool--don't only value things that you have learned personally. Take the advice of these wise men and let it affect the way you live your life.

data.title: God's Hate List
data.content:
Yeah, we know God's loving, but there are some things he hates too.

They are constant liars,

a nudge of the foot, or the wiggle of fingers.
Their perverted hearts plot evil,
and they constantly stir up trouble.
But they will be destroyed suddenly,
broken in an instant beyond all hope of healing.

There are six things the LORD hates--
no, seven things he detests:
haughty eyes,
a lying tongue,
hands that kill the innocent,
a heart that plots evil,
feet that race to do wrong,
a false witness who pours out lies,
a person who sows discord in a family.

Are there habits in your life you need to get rid of?

data.title: God's Character: He Knows Everything
data.content:
God would win on Jeopardy. Wanna know why? He's omniscient. He knows everything about everything. Especially you.

Psalm 139:1-4

O LORD, you have examined my heart
and know everything about me.
You know when I sit down or stand up.
You know my every thought when far away.
You chart the path ahead of me
and tell me where to stop and rest.
Every moment you know where I am.
You know what I am going to say
even before I say it, LORD.

Think about it. God knows every detail of your life and every thought you have. So next time you feel alone...remember, God knows where you are every moment. And he's there to give you rest.

data.title: Seedly Wisdom
data.content:
Today, some gardening tips from

Matthew 13:18-23

"Now listen to the explanation of the parable about the farmer planting the seeds:

"The seed that fell on the footpath represents those who hear the message about the Kingdom and don't understand it. Then the evil one comes and snatches away the seed that was planted in their hearts.

"The seed on the rocky soil represents those who hear the message and immediately receive it with joy. But since they don't have deep roots, they don't last long. They fall away as soon as they have problems or are persecuted for believing God's word.

"The seed that fell among the thorns represents those who hear God's word, but all too quickly the message is crowded out by the worries of this life and the lure of wealth, so no fruit is produced.

"The seed that fell on good soil represents those who truly hear and understand God's word and produce a harvest of thirty, sixty, or even a hundred times as much as had been planted!"

data.title: God's Got Your Back?
data.content:
Ever wonder if God's really got your back?

Romans 8:31-37

What shall we say about such wonderful things as these? If God is for us, who can ever be against us? Since he did not spare even his own Son but gave him up for us all, won't he also give us everything else? Who dares accuse us whom God has chosen for his own? No one--for God himself has given us right standing with himself. Who then will condemn us? No one--for Christ Jesus died for us and was raised to life for us, and he is sitting in the place of honor at God's right hand, pleading for us.

Can anything ever separate us from Christ's love? Does it mean he no longer loves us if we have trouble or calamity, or are persecuted, or hungry, or destitute, or in danger, or threatened with death? (As the Scriptures say, "For your sake we are killed every day; we are being slaughtered like sheep.") No, despite all these things, overwhelming victory is ours through Christ, who loved us.

The next time you're feeling insecure, remember God is on your side.

data.title: Greater Than the Sum of Your Parts
data.content:
Scientists have figured out that the human body is about 65% oxygen, 18% carbon, and a little bit of a lot of other elements. And to buy those same elements, it would cost about 4 or 5 dollars. Add this to all the other messages we hear every day trying to convince us that we are worth less than we think we are. God doesn't see us as worthless. Here's another message you need to hear.

Matthew 10:29-31

"What is the price of two sparrows--one copper coin? But not a single sparrow can fall to the ground without your Father knowing it. And the very hairs on your head are all numbered.

So don't be afraid; you are more valuable to God than a whole flock of sparrows."

No matter what any scientist says, you are not worthless. No matter what the commercials say, what the critics say, what the other kids at school say, you are valuable. More than that, you're priceless and you matter to God.

data.title: Almost Owe Nothing
data.content:
Debt is a burden. In Romans 13:8 it mentions debt, and another kind of debt we owe to one another.

Romans 13:8

Owe nothing to anyone--except for your obligation to love one another. If you love your neighbor, you will fulfill the requirements of God's law.

Approach everyone you meet as if you owe them. Act as if you owe them love. Now that's a debt the world can handle.

data.title: God's Character: Holy
data.content:
Holiness is a tricky concept. It means to be completely "other," to be set apart for something special. Here's what Peter said about us and being holy.

1 Peter 1:14-15

Obey God because you are his children. Don't slip back into your old ways of doing evil; you didn't know any better then. But now you must be holy in everything you do, just as God--who chose you to be his children--is holy.

Now being holy doesn't mean we think we're better than other people or even that we're perfect. It means we live the way God asks us to, counting on him to help us be different than we used to be. Set apart. Holy.

data.title: At Your Fingertips
data.content:
No pain, no gain! If you want to look good for someone, you have to work for it. And looking good for God is the same way. And it's worth it. Listen to what God has for you.

Proverbs 3:11-18,21

My son, do not despise the LORD's discipline
and do not resent his rebuke,

because the LORD disciplines those he loves,
as a father the son he delights in.

Blessed is the man who finds wisdom,
the man who gains understanding,

for she is more profitable than silver
and yields better returns than gold.

She is more precious than rubies;
nothing you desire can compare with her.

Long life is in her right hand;
in her left hand are riches and honor.

Her ways are pleasant ways,
and all her paths are peace.

She is a tree of life to those who embrace her;
those who lay hold of her will be blessed.

...

My son...do not let them out of your sight.

We can't get back to the garden of Eden. But wisdom, love, God's ways, his discipline--the tools of paradise--are all right here, waiting for you. For full details, see the Bible.

data.title: Remember. Remember.
data.content:
Have you ever used flash cards? It's memorization through repetition; repeating something until you know it so well you don’t really have to think about it. Think about that as you listen to

Psalm 136:23-26

He remembered us in our weakness.
His faithful love endures forever.

He saved us from our enemies.
His faithful love endures forever.

He gives food to every living thing.
His faithful love endures forever.

Give thanks to the God of heaven.
His faithful love endures forever.

Feeling forgotten? God's faithful love endures forever. Feel like everyone’s against you? God's faithful love endures forever. Whatever you're facing today, God's faithful love endures forever.

data.content:
It's the hardest question of all: "Where is God?" Well, these verses have the answer.

Isaiah 41:9-10

"For I have chosen you
and will not throw you away.
Don't be afraid, for I am with you.
Don't be discouraged, for I am your God.
I will strengthen you and help you.
I will hold you up with my victorious right hand."

Where is God? The answer is, he's with you.

data.title: Abilities
data.content:
YOU--are important.

Romans 12:4-9

Just as our bodies have many parts and each part has a special function, so it is with Christ's body. We are many parts of one body, and we all belong to each other.

In his grace, God has given us different gifts for doing certain things well. So if God has given you the ability to prophesy, speak out with as much faith as God has given you. If your gift is serving others, serve them well. If you are a teacher, teach well. If your gift is to encourage others, be encouraging. If it is giving, give generously. If God has given you leadership ability, take the responsibility seriously. And if you have a gift for showing kindness to others, do it gladly.

Don't just pretend to love others. Really love them.

You know, the abilities God's given you, no matter what they are, they're important. We need you to use them! If you don't, it's like part of our body is asleep. We need YOU!

data.title: The Jesus Way
data.content:
Jesus had his own way of doing things. Take in what he said about dealing with those people that you don't like--or who just don't like you. Here's Jesus:

Matthew 5:43-48

"You have heard the law that says, 'Love your neighbor and hate your enemy.' But I say, love your enemies! Pray for those who persecute you! In that way, you will be acting as true children of your Father in heaven. For he gives his sunlight to both the evil and the good, and he sends rain on the just and the unjust alike. If you love only those who love you, what reward is there for that? Even corrupt tax collectors do that much. If you are kind only to your friends, how are you different from anyone else? Even pagans do that. But you are to be perfect, even as your Father in heaven is perfect."

Ok, love your enemies--you can't do that on your own power. So, ask God to help you. And, "be perfect?" Right. Well, that happens only through Christ.

data.title: What to Do?
data.content:
We've all felt angry, irrational, fearful, controlling or resentful. The question is: What do we do with those feelings? How about a Psalm? Here's Psalm 91. Take a listen.

Psalm 91:1-7

Those who live in the shelter of the Most High
will find rest in the shadow of the Almighty.
This I declare about the LORD:
He alone is my refuge, my place of safety;
he is my God, and I trust him.
For he will rescue you from every trap
and protect you from deadly disease.
He will cover you with his feathers.
He will shelter you with his wings.
His faithful promises are your armor and protection.
Do not be afraid of the terrors of the night,
nor the arrow that flies in the day.
Do not dread the disease that stalks in darkness,
nor the disaster that strikes at midday.
Though a thousand fall at your side,
though ten thousand are dying around you,
these evils will not touch you.

God's truth can disinfect your baggage.

data.content:
When you feel like you're at the bottom, pay attention to the Lord's words in these verses.

Jeremiah 29:11-13

"For I know the plans I have for you," says the Lord. "They are plans for good and not for disaster, to give you a future and a hope. In those days when you pray, I will listen. If you look for me wholeheartedly, you will find me."

We absolutely can't forget to look for him.

data.title: The Bible & You: A Deep Foundation
data.content:
Today, a metaphor for what it's like to apply God's Word to your life.

Luke 6:47-48

"I will show you what it's like when someone comes to me, listens to my teaching, and then follows it. It is like a person building a house who digs deep and lays the foundation on solid rock. When the floodwaters rise and break against that house, it stands firm because it is well built."

You want to be grounded, to have a good foundation, to stand firm even when life gets hard? It all starts with hearing and applying God's Word. So start digging those holes and laying those bricks. It's foundation-building time.

data.title: Going the Right Way
data.content:
Ok, so you know the right thing to do, but everybody else is going the other way. That can make things tough--and let's face it, it gets lonely. Here's some encouragement for you to do things God's way, no matter what.

Psalm 1:1-6

Oh, the joys of those who do not
follow the advice of the wicked,
or stand around with sinners,
or join in with mockers.
But they delight in the law of the LORD,
meditating on it day and night.
They are like trees planted along the riverbank,
bearing fruit each season.
Their leaves never wither,
and they prosper in all they do.

But not the wicked!
They are like worthless chaff, scattered by the wind.
They will be condemned at the time of judgment.
Sinners will have no place among the godly.
For the LORD watches over the path of the godly,
but the path of the wicked leads to destruction.

So stay on the right path. You'll be glad you did.

data.title: The Bible & You: Just Read It
data.content:
Ok. So we talk about how powerful the Bible is and how much we should all read it, right? But have you ever thought about how Jesus knew the Bible? Which means he read it.

Matthew 4:1-4

Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted there by the devil. For forty days and forty nights he fasted and became very hungry. During that time the devil came and said to him, "If you are the Son of God, tell these stones to become loaves of bread." But Jesus told him, "No! The Scriptures say, 'People do not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of God.'"

Jesus, who is God, studied and knew the Scriptures. In this story, that helped him battle temptation, and who doesn't need that in life? So if Jesus needed the power of the Bible, figures we do too.

data.title: Costly
data.content:
Hope. What do you do when the world is crashing down? What are you willing to give to see your hope fulfilled? Hope is what Judas gave up, and what John the Baptist managed to cling to.

Matthew 11:2-6

John the Baptist, who was in prison, heard about all the things the Messiah was doing. So he sent his disciples to ask Jesus, "Are you the Messiah we've been expecting, or should we keep looking for someone else?"

Jesus told them, "Go back to John and tell him what you have heard and seen--the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cured, the deaf hear, the dead are raised to life, and the Good News is being preached to the poor. And tell him, 'God blesses those who do not turn away because of me.'"

Jesus basically gave John the Baptist, his cousin, a death sentence. Because John refused to denounce Christ like Judas did, John lost his life. Sometimes it costs so much just to hold on, but, someday, if we keep the faith, we who only have only a handful of verses will see him face to face. Keep on hoping.

data.title: Being Neighborly
data.content:
Hey, did you know Christ says that the greatest commandment is to love God and love your neighbor as yourself? You know who knew this? John:

1 John 4:7-12

Dear friends, let us continue to love one another, for love comes from God. Anyone who loves is a child of God and knows God. But anyone who does not love does not know God, for God is love.

God showed how much he loved us by sending his one and only Son into the world so that we might have eternal life through him. This is real love--not that we loved God, but that he loved us and sent his Son as a sacrifice to take away our sins.

Dear friends, since God loved us that much, we surely ought to love each other. No one has ever seen God. But if we love each other, God lives in us, and his love is brought to full expression in us.

Love to the fullest extent. Love until the end.

data.title: Prayer: For Us
data.content:
Have you ever wondered what Jesus prayed about? Well...wonder no longer.

John 17:20-21

"I am praying not only for these disciples but also for all who will ever believe in me through their message. I pray that they will all be one, just as you and I are one--as you are in me, Father, and I am in you. And may they be in us so that the world will believe you sent me."

Jesus prayed for us. That we'd work together, and get along. It's crazy, right? That Jesus loved and prayed not only for the people who were his friends way back then, but for us in the 21st century! Take a couple moments today to think about that and know that you are loved. Then, follow his example and pray for a friend.

data.title: Common Sense
data.content:
Common sense and discernment are valuable things. Part of common sense is helping people when you can.

Proverbs 3:21-28

My child, don't lose sight of common sense and discernment.
Hang on to them,
for they will refresh your soul.
They are like jewels on a necklace.
They keep you safe on your way,
and your feet will not stumble.
You can go to bed without fear;
you will lie down and sleep soundly.
You need not be afraid of sudden disaster
or the destruction that comes upon the wicked,
for the Lord is your security.
He will keep your foot from being caught in a trap.

Do not withhold good from those who deserve it
when it's in your power to help them.
If you can help your neighbor now, don't say,
"Come back tomorrow, and then I'll help you."

It's easy to put good things off for another day. But when we don't, generally things will go better for us. We place ourselves in the path of God's work. And in that path comes his security and refreshment.

data.title: Fruitful Living: The Proof
data.content:
Remember the WWJD bracelets? The idea behind them was two-fold. First, to remind you to think about what you do before you do it, and second, to let everyone in the whole entire world know you're a Christian. But God's way for us to show we're his followers is very different from that.

John 13:35

Your love for one another will prove to the world that you are my disciples.

See, it's not a bracelet with a clever slogan that proves we follow Jesus. It's how we treat each other. So, step it up. Be patient, be thoughtful, help out.

data.title: Smarty Pants
data.content:
Pop quiz: What's the square root of 16 over 4? What is a hypotenuse? How do you bisect a marmoset or answer Schrodinger's cat? If you're thinking, Who even remembers this stuff?, read on.

Proverbs 3:1-6

My son, do not forget my teaching,
but keep my commands in your heart,
for they will prolong your life many years
and bring you prosperity.
Let love and faithfulness never leave you;
bind them around your neck,
write them on the tablet of your heart.
Then you will win favor and a good name
in the sight of God and man.
Trust in the LORD with all your heart
and lean not on your own understanding;
in all your ways acknowledge him,
and he will make your paths straight.

With today's technology, it's easier than ever to access God's instructions...or the definition of a hypotenuse. Don't forget to let God's words sink in. God isn't going to give you a pop quiz at the end, He'll be more interested with who you are at heart and what you've done.

data.title: Anger: Be Slow
data.content:
Have you ever seen the old Incredible Hulk TV show? You have this mild-mannered scientist who has this big problem: whenever he gets mad he turns into a huge, green monster. God does not want you to be the Hulk.

James 1:19-20

My dear brothers and sisters, be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to get angry. Your anger can never make things right in God's sight.

So when you feel your inner Hulk starting to come out, stop yourself and remember this verse--and be slow to get angry.

data.title: Loneliness: Be Like Jesus
data.content:
Today, a look at loneliness in the life of Jesus. It's in Mark 14:32-38.

They went to the olive grove called Gethsemane, and Jesus said, "Sit here while I go and pray." He took Peter, James and John with him and he became deeply troubled and distressed, he told them, "My soul is crushed with grief to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch with me."

He went on a little farther and fell to the ground. He prayed that, if it were possible, the awful hour awaiting him might pass him by. "Abba, Father," he cried out, "everything is possible for you. Please take this cup of suffering away from me. Yet I want your will to be done, not mine."

Then he returned and found the disciples asleep. He said to Peter, "Simon, are you asleep? Couldn't you watch with me even one hour?"

Even though Jesus was God, he needed the support of his friends. And there's something comforting about that. If you're dealing with loneliness, don't let fear or pride or anything else keep you from calling a friend. It's what Jesus did.

data.title: Heaven: Hope Will Follow
data.content:
Hope is a weird thing. It isn't easy to get ahold of when life gets hard. But, Christians have a reason to hope.

John 14:1-3

"Don't let your hearts be troubled. Trust in God, and trust in me. There is more than enough room in my Father's home. If this were not so, would I have told you that I am going to prepare a place for you? When everything is ready, I will come and get you, so that you will always be with me where I am."

That passage starts off with one simple phrase: don't be troubled. Jesus said this to his friends right before he was arrested and killed. Seems like a lot to ask, doesn't it, to trust him when the worst was about to happen? But he did ask for their trust, and he asks us for the same. Trust in Jesus and hope will follow. It's that simple. So take comfort and don't be troubled.

data.title: Living for God: #1 Goal
data.content:
Do you have any life goals? Here's one from Paul:

2 Corinthians 5:8-9

Yes, we are fully confident, and we would rather be away from these earthly bodies, for then we will be at home with the Lord. So whether we are here in this body or away from this body, our goal is to please him.

More than dieting, more than retirement, this is far more important. Live so you honor and please God.

data.title: Salvation: Set Free
data.content:
Did you know that once you didn't have much of a choice but to sin?

Romans 6:6-8,11

We know that our old sinful selves were crucified with Christ so that sin might lose its power in our lives. We are no longer slaves to sin. For when we died with Christ we were set free from the power of sin. And since we died with Christ, we know we will also live with him. So you also should consider yourselves to be dead to the power of sin and alive to God through Christ Jesus.

So next time you feel tempted to sin, remember, you are no longer under its power. You were set free by Jesus.

data.title: Makin' Mistakes
data.content:
You know, we all make mistakes. So here's some good news.

1 John 2:1-6

My dear children, I am writing this to you so that you will not sin. But if anyone does sin, we have an advocate who pleads our case before the Father. He is Jesus Christ, the one who is truly righteous. He himself is the sacrifice that atones for our sins--and not only our sins but the sins of all the world.

And we can be sure that we know him if we obey his commandments. If someone claims, "I know God," but doesn't obey God's commandments, that person is a liar and is not living in the truth. But those who obey God's word truly show how completely they love him. That is how we know we are living in him. Those who say they live in God should live their lives as Jesus did.

If you've blown it today, talk to God about it.

data.title: Lemuel's Mother
data.content:
Moms have some great advice. Maybe your mother taught you things like how to sort your laundry according to color. How to treat and respect the opposite sex. How to always--always--eat homemade pesto the day you make it, because it just doesn't keep very well in the fridge. Wait, she didn't teach you that? Oh.

Well, today's passage comes from Proverbs. It's a bit of ancient motherly advice to a non-Jewish king named Lemuel. His mother was pretty wise. So he wrote down some stuff she said.

Proverbs 31:1,8-9

The sayings of King Lemuel contain this message, which his mother taught him.
...
Speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves;
ensure justice for those being crushed.
Yes, speak up for the poor and helpless,
and see that they get justice.

Do you know someone that needs you to be their voice? Take the advice of Lemuel's mom. Be their voice.

data.title: Heaven: All Things New
data.content:
Today, a glimpse of heaven from Revelation 21:1-5.

Then I saw a new heaven and a new earth, for the old heaven and the old earth had disappeared. And the sea was also gone. And I saw the holy city, the new Jerusalem, coming down from God out of heaven like a bride beautifully dressed for her husband.

I heard a loud shout from the throne, saying, "Look, God's home is now among his people! He will live with them, and they will be his people. God himself will be with them. He will wipe every tear from their eyes, and there will be no more death or sorrow or crying or pain. All these things are gone forever."

And the one sitting on the throne said, "Look, I am making everything new!" And then he said to me, "Write this down, for what I tell you is trustworthy and true."

Just think--everything will be made new. Everything. No more war. No more tears. No more pollution or hate. Everything will be new. It can't come soon enough.

data.title: Assurance: Now What?
data.content:
So great! You've decided to follow Jesus. All that's left is to learn how you're supposed to live...for the rest of your life. Here's a little help from Ephesians 4:29-32:

Don't use foul or abusive language. Let everything you say be good and helpful, so that your words will be an encouragement to those who hear them.

And do not bring sorrow to God's Holy Spirit by the way you live. Remember, he has identified you as his own, guaranteeing that you will be saved on the day of redemption.

Get rid of all bitterness, rage, anger, harsh words, and slander, as well as all types of evil behavior. Instead, be kind to each other, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, just as God through Christ has forgiven you

When it's all said and done, it comes down to this: God gives us the power to become like Jesus. That process isn't always easy, but you'll find that the changes in your life and relationships will be worth it.

data.title: Heaven: Hope Will Follow
data.content:
Hope is a weird thing. It isn't easy to get ahold of when life gets hard. But, Christians have a reason to hope.

John 14:1-3

"Don't let your hearts be troubled. Trust in God, and trust in me. There is more than enough room in my Father's home. If this were not so, would I have told you that I am going to prepare a place for you? When everything is ready, I will come and get you, so that you will always be with me where I am."

That passage starts off with one simple phrase: don't be troubled. Jesus said this to his friends right before he was arrested and killed. Seems like a lot to ask, doesn't it, to trust him when the worst was about to happen? But he did ask for their trust, and he asks us for the same. Trust in Jesus and hope will follow. It's that simple. So take comfort and don't be troubled.

data.title: Overcoming Epic Odds
data.content:
All right: Aslan defeating the White Witch; Frodo tossing a small ring into the mountain volcano; Luke Skywalker blowing up the Death Star...

In every story there is a climax. All the events in any good story build to a point--a point of change--where the obstacles are faced head-on, and the odds are overcome. Like Jesus on the cross. And at some point after the climax comes a resolution.

The Bible talks about a coming resolution in human history--a time when the world will be remade.

2 Peter 3:8-14

But you must not forget this one thing, dear friends: A day is like a thousand years to the Lord, and a thousand years is like a day. The Lord isn't really being slow about his promise, as some people think. No, he is being patient for your sake. He does not want anyone to be destroyed, but wants everyone to repent. But the day of the Lord will come as unexpectedly as a thief. Then the heavens will pass away with a terrible noise, and the very elements themselves will disappear in fire, and the earth and everything on it will be found to deserve judgment.

Since everything around us is going to be destroyed like this, what holy and godly lives you should live, looking forward to the day of God and hurrying it along. On that day, he will set the heavens on fire, and the elements will melt away in the flames. But we are looking forward to the new heavens and new earth he has promised, a world filled with God's righteousness.

And so, dear friends, while you are waiting for these things to happen, make every effort to be found living peaceful lives that are pure and blameless in his sight.

The big resolution to the story is coming! God will one day create a new heaven and earth. So let's live in anticipation of that day.

data.title: Burning Coals
data.content:
I had a lot of reactions to my return to a nanny job this school year. None were pleasant.

Her kids have so many toys and they still complain about wanting more.

I don't understand why people have kids, and then pay other people to raise them.

They're not even giving me a raise this year.

I restrict my major grievances to the privacy of our home. To other people, I make only a short grunt and reply, "Well, we need the money."

Naturally, I expected my first days back to be full of spoiled brats and unappreciative bosses.

I walk in. My boss, Clara, says, "I bought you that coffee you like. I know it's hard being here so early in the morning. But I had to guess on the creamer you like...is this right? And I got your favorite jelly. Here's some money if you want to take the kids out to lunch, since school hasn't started yet. Get yourself something too."

You know that proverb about heaping burning coals? "If your enemies are hungry, give them food to eat. If they are thirsty, give them water to drink. You will heap burning coals of shame on their heads..." (Proverbs 25:21-22). It's not like Clara thinks I'm her enemy--or vice versa. But my scalp definitely felt singed.

It makes me sick sometimes, the thoughts that go through my head. Even more nauseating is the praise I grant myself for letting them go unknown. But I'm starting to think some of my opinions can do the bulk of their damage without ever leaving my lips.

In Romans 12:21, Paul quotes those proverbs when he talks about revenge. He follows the verses with this: "Don't let evil conquer you, but conquer evil by doing good."

I had already been conquered. I chose to let judgment and indignation stew. This repulsive aroma drifts about and sticks to the fabric of my heart. And those are some tough stains to remove.

Sometimes the best good I can do has less to do with my hands or my money or my time, but with my heart.

June

data.content:

Proverbs 14:16-17

The wise are cautious and avoid danger; fools plunge ahead with great confidence. Those who are short-tempered do foolish things, and schemers are hated.

We all know we don't make the best decisions when we're angry. It is, literally, common sense. But putting that knowledge into practice is something else. So make a concerted effort today to turn common sense into common practice.

data.title: Practically Wise
data.content:
We're all pretty aware that God's wisdom is spiritual, but did you know that it's also pretty practical?

Proverbs 19:16-25

Keep the commandments and keep your life;
despising them leads to death.

If you help the poor, you are lending to the LORD--
and he will repay you!

Discipline your children while there is hope.
Otherwise you will ruin their lives.

Hot-tempered people must pay the penalty.
If you rescue them once, you will have to do it again.

Get all the advice and instruction you can,
so you will be wise the rest of your life.

You can make many plans,
but the LORD's purpose will prevail.

Loyalty makes a person attractive.
It is better to be poor than dishonest.

Fear of the LORD leads to life,
bringing security and protection from harm.

Lazy people take food in their hand
but don't even lift it to their mouth.

If you punish a mocker, the simpleminded will learn a lesson;
if you correct the wise, they will be all the wiser.

Love God's commands. Learn his wisdom. Live in joy.

data.title: Good Things are Coming
data.content:
God knows how hard things are, and that life can crush us. That's why the Bible has so many things to say to the discouraged.

Isaiah 61:1-3

The Spirit of the Sovereign LORD is upon me,
for the LORD has anointed me
to bring good news to the poor.
He has sent me to comfort the brokenhearted
and to proclaim that captives will be released
and prisoners will be freed.
He has sent me to tell those who mourn
that the time of the LORD's favor has come,
and with it, the day of God's anger against their enemies.
To all who mourn in Israel,
he will give a crown of beauty for ashes,
a joyous blessing instead of mourning,
festive praise instead of despair.
In their righteousness, they will be like great oaks
that the LORD has planted for his own glory.

God knows how bad things are, but he promises they won't stay that way. Soon we'll trade all this suffering for something much better. Don't give up. Put your hope in God.

Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Christ has become a child of God. And everyone who loves the Father loves his children, too. We know we love God's children if we love God and obey his commandments. Loving God means keeping his commandments, and his commandments are not burdensome.

So it may sound strange to be commanded to love people. In our culture, love has become all about how we feel. But our obedient love for God and our love for people go beyond our feelings to how we act. And what changes this world more than love? So go ahead. It's your move.

data.title: Simple Prayer
data.content:
Prayer is one of those things that I often talk about, but I don't always do. Like, "Hey, wow, that's tough. I'll pray for you." "We should really pray about that." "Prayer? I'm a prayer warrior!" "Yes, I love prayer!"

And yet, sometimes I don't pray. Sometimes for days. Sometimes weeks. Praying is as simple as listening and communicating with God.

1 Thessalonians 5:25

Dear brothers and sisters, pray for us.

Luke 18:1

One day Jesus told his disciples a story to show that they should always pray and never give up.

1 Thessalonians 5:17

Never stop praying.

So let's do some praying today. In fact, after you're finished reading this, take a moment and pray for someone who needs it. Right now. If no one comes to mind just pick a family member or a friend. It's a simple act that can make all the difference.

data.title: God's Character: He Loves Us
data.content:
How much does God love us? (And by "us" I mean everyone in the world.) You know this one, I bet. But do you know it?

John 3:16-17

For God loved the world so much that he gave his one and only Son, so that everyone who believes in him will not perish but have eternal life. God sent his Son into the world not to judge the world, but to save the world through him.

You've probably seen people on TV at professional football games holding a sign with John 3:16 written on it. It's like the most recognizable verse in the whole Bible. But don't let the familiarity keep you from really thinking about what it means. Gave God his Son. His only Son. Because he's on a mission to rescue the world, and by "the world" I mean us. He loves us.

You take the worship with you. Worship is not about being with your favorite friends, your favorite music, or even being in your favorite church--as beloved as those things may be. Jesus talked with a woman about worship.

Jesus replied, "Believe me, dear woman, the time is coming when it will no longer matter whether you worship the Father on this mountain or in Jerusalem. You Samaritans know very little about the one you worship, while we Jews know all about him, for salvation comes through the Jews. For God is Spirit, so those who worship him must worship in spirit and in truth."

data.title: To All the Single Ladies/Fellas
data.content:
"If you can handle the crushing loneliness and bitter tears, then singleness is definitely the way to go," a (single) friend of mine joked the other day. And he's not a Christian, but his words reminded me of someone else who was.

"So I say to those who aren't married and to widows--it's better to stay unmarried, just as I am. But if they can't control themselves, they should go ahead and marry. It's better to marry than to burn with lust" (1 Corinthians 7:8-9).

Not a Bible verse for the weddings, that one. "If you can't keep your pants on, I guess you'd better get married." Makes it sound easy.

I guess it gives us singles a leg to stand on ("I may not get to be married, or get to go home to someone or have sex or share all my deepest thoughts and emotions with my one true love, but at least I'm obeying God!") But it also creates a little night terror.

Could my current singleness be because (gulp) God wants it that way? Like, for good? As in, "get ye comfortable in that single mattress, Joe, because such is my sovereign plan for you." Are you blessing me with the gift of celibacy, God? If so, did you keep the receipt?

You know. When you just can't find anyone that you're crazy about--or, worse, when nobody you're crazy about is interested--strange questions start popping up. And keeping me up nights. The only answer I really get, as usual, is Jesus.

If I can't control myself and if marriage is truly a need--which, the older I get, the more I become convinced that it is--then it's one Jesus will meet. Because Paul also says, "And this same God who takes care of me will supply all your needs from his glorious riches, which have been given to us in Christ Jesus" (Philippians 4:19).

And That'll Do for Now,
Joe

data.title: Changing the Way You Live
data.content:
Right now is the time for you to change the way you live. Here's Paul in Colossians.

Colossians 3:5-11

So put to death the sinful, earthly things lurking within you. Have nothing to do with sexual immorality, impurity, lust, and evil desires. Don't be greedy, for a greedy person is an idolater, worshiping the things of this world. Because of these sins, the anger of God is coming. You used to do these things when your life was still part of this world. But now is the time to get rid of anger, rage, malicious behavior, slander, and dirty language. Don't lie to each other, for you have stripped off your old sinful nature and all its wicked deeds. Put on your new nature, and be renewed as you learn to know your Creator and become like him. In this new life, it doesn't matter if you are a Jew or a Gentile, circumcised or uncircumcised, barbaric, uncivilized, slave, or free. Christ is all that matters, and he lives in all of us.

So take a second: What's one thing you can work on today? Christ lives in you.

data.title: Fruitful Living: Dealing With Trouble
data.content:
So picture this. You wake up and you stub your toe, then stumble downstairs just to find out that someone in the house has eaten the last of the cereal which means you head off to work hungry. Then you get stuck in traffic and you're late for the third time this week and your boss decides that's one too many times. Good day, right?

James 1:2-3

Dear brothers and sisters, whenever trouble comes your way, let it be an opportunity for great joy. For you know that when your faith is tested, your endurance has a chance to grow.

This might be one of the most difficult teachings in the Bible. It requires an incredible amount of trust that God is still working for good, even though the circumstances say differently. So if you're dealing with some trouble right now, look for how it's helping you grow. Look for joy.

data.title: Fruitful Living: Changed by the Spirit
data.content:
Odds are, if you asked any random person if they'd like to have more joy or peace or self-control in their lives they'd say, "Uhh...yeah! But how?" Well, listen to this from Galatians 5:22-25:

But the Holy Spirit produces this kind of fruit in our lives: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control. There is no law against these things!

Yeah, it's God's Spirit that makes these changes in us. And here's our part:

Those who belong to Christ Jesus have nailed the passions and desires of their sinful nature to his cross and crucified them there. Since we are living by the Spirit, let us follow the Spirit's leading in every part of our lives.

It's a lifelong process, this fruit-growing thing. Which is kind of exciting.

data.title: God's Character: The Power of Love
data.content:
It might be easy to imagine God as the all-powerful deity in the sky ready to squish you at every turn. But here's a description of God that squishes that idea.

Psalm 147:3-5

He heals the brokenhearted,
binding up their wounds.
He counts the stars
and calls them all by name.
How great is our Lord! His power is absolute!
His understanding is beyond comprehension!

The writer of Psalm 147 leads with a statement about God's kindness. And that can be easy to lose sight of when you think about his power. God names and numbers the stars--and yet his heart is tender enough, his love is big enough, to heal a broken heart. So that's what's so staggeringly beautiful about God. Not just his immense power...but also his limitless love.

data.title: God's Character: Beyond Our Brains
data.content:
We have a hard time understanding God's love for us, but that doesn't change it. Listen to this from Ephesians 3:18-19:

And may you have the power to understand, as all God's people should, how wide, how long, how high, and how deep his love is. May you experience the love of Christ, though it is too great to understand fully. Then you will be made complete with all the fullness of life and power that comes from God.

Did you catch that? Though God's love is beyond our brain's power to comprehend, we can still experience it. It will still make all the difference in our lives. That's the Apostle Paul's true prayer for the Ephesians: that they experience God's love to the fullest. And that's our prayer for you.

data.title: God's Character: Measuring Love
data.content:
Have you sometimes wondered how much a person loves you? That may be difficult to measure, but we actually know how much God loves us. It says so in 1 John 4:9-10.

God showed how much he loved us by sending his only Son into the world so that we might have eternal life through him. This is real love. It is not that we loved God, but that he loved us and sent his Son as a sacrifice to take away our sins.

See, real love doesn't have to be reciprocated. It's just given. God loved us when we didn't even know who he was. And he showed it by sending Jesus. Think about that today.

data.title: On a Mission
data.content:
In The Blues Brothers, Jake and Elwood were two well-dressed misfits in black ties who were on a "mission from God." Jesus was also on a mission from God, a true mission, to glorify God and not himself. John recorded this.

John 7:16-18

So Jesus told them, "My message is not my own; it comes from God who sent me. Anyone who wants to do the will of God will know whether my teaching is from God or is merely my own. Those who speak for themselves want glory only for themselves, but a person who seeks to honor the one who sent him speaks truth, not lies."

Jesus was on earth to honor God who sent him. Our mission is similar today. Rather than seeking glory or power or wealth for yourself, spend your life seeking the glory of the One who sent you to share the truth with those around you.

data.title: The Good Side of Death
data.content:
Nothing you can say can erase the pain that death brings. When someone you care about dies, it's like waking up blind. We won't try to fix that--we never could. But Paul's words to the Corinthians aren't trying to fix anything, they just tell the truth about death.

1 Corinthians 15:42-44

It is the same way with the resurrection of the dead. Our earthly bodies are planted in the ground when we die, but they will be raised to live forever. Our bodies are buried in brokenness, but they will be raised in glory. They are buried in weakness, but they will be raised in strength. They are buried as natural human bodies, but they will be raised as spiritual bodies. For just as there are natural bodies, there are also spiritual bodies.

It doesn't actually make the pain go away, but remember: God has a plan for our death, just like he has a plan for our lives. Just because it's hard doesn't mean it's not true.

data.title: Can You Earn It?
data.content:
Are you worried that you haven't done enough to earn God's love? Here's some good news from the Apostle Paul.

Ephesians 2:4-10

But God is so rich in mercy, and he loved us so much, that even though we were dead because of our sins, he gave us life when he raised Christ from the dead. (It is only by God's grace that you have been saved!) For he raised us from the dead along with Christ and seated us with him in the heavenly realms because we are united with Christ Jesus. So God can point to us in all future ages as examples of the incredible wealth of his grace and kindness toward us, as shown in all he has done for us who are united with Christ Jesus.

God saved you by his grace when you believed. And you can't take credit for this; it is a gift from God. Salvation is not a reward for the good things we have done, so none of us can boast about it. For we are God's masterpiece. He has created us anew in Christ Jesus, so we can do the good things he planned for us long ago.

God's love is based on who he is, not what you've done. See, told you it was good news!

data.title: Sheep-like
data.content:
Ever wonder why we're compared to sheep so much in the Bible? Well, there are a few reasons, but as a sheep gets to know its shepherd, it will only follow him.

John 10:7-10

"I tell you the truth, I am the gate for the sheep. All who came before me were thieves and robbers. But the true sheep did not listen to them. Yes, I am the gate. Those who come in through me will be saved. They will come and go freely and will find good pastures. The thief's purpose is to steal and kill and destroy. My purpose is to give them a rich and satisfying life."

Don't let others fool you. Jesus is the way, the truth and the light.

data.title: Blind Leading the Blind
data.content:
It's like, the pot calling the kettle black; looking for a speck in your friend's eye when there's a block of wood in your own; the blind leading the blind; the glazed donut telling the frosted donut that he's missing something right in the middle.

Jesus warns us against judging others, or judgment will come to us as well. He talks about this in Luke:

Luke 6:37-40

"Do not judge others, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn others, or it will all come back against you. Forgive others, and you will be forgiven. Give, and you will receive. Your gift will return to you in full--pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, running over, and poured into your lap. The amount you give will determine the amount you get back."

Then Jesus gave the following illustration: "Can one blind person lead another? Won't they both fall into a ditch? Students are not greater than their teacher. But the student who is fully trained will become like the teacher."

The Son of Man came to seek and save what was lost. And you, as his follower, are to be seeking those that are lost as well. Let God be the judge. You give of yourself and seek to serve the lost around you. Bring them closer to him.

data.title: Giving Love
data.content:
Do me a favor, focus on this one thing today. Try to share love with everyone you encounter--friends, strangers, even people who've annoyed you in the past. That's what Jesus asks of us in John 15. But sometimes it takes consciously doing it to see the impact.

John 15:12-17

This is my commandment: Love each other in the same way I have loved you. There is no greater love than to lay down one's life for one's friends. You are my friends if you do what I command. I no longer call you slaves, because a master doesn't confide in his slaves. Now you are my friends, since I have told you everything the Father told me. You didn't choose me. I chose you. I appointed you to go and produce lasting fruit, so that the Father will give you whatever you ask for, using my name. This is my command: Love each other.

So go love some people today. And remind yourself how much Jesus loves you.

data.title: Flip-flop
data.content:
If Jesus wasn't, you know, Jesus, don't you think he'd be thinking, "Now that I've served you guys, it's time for you to serve me." I mean, he did wash people's feet! You'd think he'd expect something in return. Fortunately, it doesn't work that way.

John 13:13-17

"You call me 'Teacher' and 'Lord,''and you are right, because that's what I am. And since I, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you ought to wash each other's feet. I have given you an example to follow. Do as I have done to you. I tell you the truth, slaves are not greater than their master. Nor is the messenger more important than the one who sends the message. Now that you know these things, God will bless you for doing them."

Mark 10:43-44

"Whoever wants to be a leader among you must be your servant, and whoever wants to be first among you must be the slave of everyone else."

So don't ask, "What's in it for me?" Just serve.

That promise is good. And it checks out. Put your trust in Jesus and bring that light back into your world.

data.title: Which Doesn't Belong?
data.content:
We're going to play a little game, so pay attention. Which of these words doesn't belong?

Love. Help. Bless. Pray. Enemy.

Okay, think you know the answer? Well, listen to what Jesus said in the Gospel of Luke.

Luke 6:27-31

"But to you who are willing to listen, I say, love your enemies! Do good to those who hate you. Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who hurt you. If someone slaps you on one cheek, offer the other cheek also. If someone demands your coat, offer your shirt also. Give to anyone who asks; and when things are taken away from you, don't try to get them back. Do to others as you would like them to do to you."

So, love, help, bless, pray, enemy--they all belong. Be different than the way people expect. It's hard sometimes, but it's so worth it.

data.title: Discipling
data.content:
We don't use the term "disciple" much anymore, unless we're talking about The Disciples--the twelve men who followed Jesus. But, the concept still exists.

John 8:28-32

So Jesus said, "When you have lifted up the Son of Man on the cross, then you will understand that I Am he. I do nothing on my own but say only what the Father taught me. And the one who sent me is with me--he has not deserted me. For I always do what pleases him." Then many who heard him say these things believed in him.

Jesus said to the people who believed in him, "You are truly my disciples if you remain faithful to my teachings. And you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free."

Being a disciple isn't just a title we wear, it's a way of life. Being Jesus' disciple today is about much more than simply knowing who he is and what he taught. Being his disciple means living the way he lived.

data.title: God Actually Does Care
data.content:
You know, God really cares about how we feel.

Ephesians 4:24-32

Put on your new nature, created to be like God--truly righteous and holy.

So stop telling lies. Let us tell our neighbors the truth, for we are all parts of the same body. And "don't sin by letting anger control you." Don't let the sun go down while you are still angry, for anger gives a foothold to the devil.

If you are a thief, quit stealing. Instead, use your hands for good hard work, and then give generously to others in need. Don't use foul or abusive language. Let everything you say be good and helpful, so that your words will be an encouragement to those who hear them.

And do not bring sorrow to God's Holy Spirit by the way you live. Remember, he has identified you as his own, guaranteeing that you will be saved on the day of redemption.

Get rid of all bitterness, rage, anger, harsh words, and slander, as well as all types of evil behavior. Instead, be kind to each other, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, just as God through Christ has forgiven you.

So what habits do you need to stop? How can you break the cycle? Stay strong.

data.title: Heaven: Hope Will Follow
data.content:
Hope is a weird thing. It isn't easy to get ahold of when life gets hard. But, Christians have a reason to hope.

John 14:1-3

"Don't let your hearts be troubled. Trust in God, and trust in me. There is more than enough room in my Father's home. If this were not so, would I have told you that I am going to prepare a place for you? When everything is ready, I will come and get you, so that you will always be with me where I am."

That passage starts off with one simple phrase: don't be troubled. Jesus said this to his friends right before he was arrested and killed. Seems like a lot to ask, doesn't it, to trust him when the worst was about to happen? But he did ask for their trust, and he asks us for the same. Trust in Jesus and hope will follow. It's that simple. So take comfort and don't be troubled.

data.title: Fear: Repeat After Me
data.content:
Did you know we're commanded in the Bible not to be afraid? It's true. In fact, it's actually one of the most used phrases in the whole, entire Bible. Here're a few examples:

Genesis 15:1

Some time later, the LORD spoke to Abram in a vision and said to him, "Do not be afraid, Abram, for I will protect you, and your reward will be great."

Joshua 1:9

"This is my command--be strong and courageous! Do not be afraid or discouraged. For the LORD your God is with you wherever you go."

Isaiah 43:1

But now, O Jacob, listen to the LORD who created you. O Israel, the one who formed you says, "Do not be afraid, for I have ransomed you. I have called you by name; you are mine."

Isaiah 44:8

"Do not tremble; do not be afraid. Did I not proclaim my purposes for you long ago? You are my witnesses--is there any other God? No! There is no other Rock-- not one!"

Matthew 14:27

But Jesus spoke to them at once. "Don't be afraid," he said. "Take courage. I am here!"

John 14:27

"I am leaving you with a gift--peace of mind and heart. And the peace I give is a gift the world cannot give. So don't be troubled or afraid."

Revelation 1:17-18

When I saw him, I fell at his feet as if I were dead. But he laid his right hand on me and said, "Don't be afraid! I am the First and the Last. I am the living one. I died, but look--I am alive forever and ever! And I hold the keys of death and the grave."

So...convinced yet?

data.title: Structure of the Bible: Poetry
data.content:
Read
The LORD is my shepherd;
I have all that I need.
He lets me rest in green meadows;
he leads me beside peaceful streams.
He renews my strength.
He guides me along right paths,
bringing honor to his name.
Even when I walk
through the darkest valley,
I will not be afraid,
for you are close beside me.
Your rod and your staff
protect and comfort me.
You prepare a feast for me
in the presence of my enemies.
You honor me by anointing my head with oil.
My cup overflows with blessings.
Surely your goodness and unfailing love will pursue me
all the days of my life,
and I will live in the house of the LORD
forever.
Psalm 23:1-6

Reflect
God demonstrated His love for his people through the beauty and power of poetry. This section of the Old Testament begins with the story of Job, a name synonymous with pain and suffering. The section ends with the Song of Songs that describes the beauty of intimacy between a husband and wife. The Book of Psalms served as Israel's songbook and is possibly the most read book of the Old Testament.

King Solomon was the writer of over 3,000 wise sayings, many of them found in the book of Proverbs. Solomon also wrote Ecclesiastes, a book that deals with the futility of chasing after anything but God.

Respond
According to Psalm 23, what does God do for His children?

Which of these poetic images resonates with you most?

data.title: Where Can I Go?
data.content:
Ever feel like you've been separated from God, and now He can't find you?

Listen to David's words in Psalm 139:7-10: "Where can I go from your Spirit? Where can I flee from your presence? If I go up to the heavens, you are there; if I make my bed in the depths, you are there. If I rise on the wings of the dawn, if I settle on the far side of the sea, even there your hand will guide me, your right hand will hold me fast."

David begins with two rhetorical questions that can only be answered with an emphatic, "Nowhere!" All of space, David explains, is saturated with God's presence. And take note: God's presence is not passive.

Wherever you are today God is right there with you. Let His hand of grace hold you fast.

data.title: Falling Short
data.content:
Read
God saved you by his grace when you believed. And you can't take credit for this; it is a gift from God. Salvation is not a reward for the good things we have done, so none of us can boast about it.
Ephesians 2:8-9

Reflect
Javier Sotomayer of Cuba currently holds the record for the men's high jump. Sotomayer jumped 8 feet and one quarter inches in 1993. His record is the longest standing record in the men's high jump. Bulgaria's Stefka Kostadinova has the longest held record in the women's high jump. In 1987, she cleared 6 feet 10 and one quarter inches.

These are amazing athletic feats. But let's really make it challenging. Suppose you set the bar at twenty feet and tried to clear it. You give it your best effort, however, each time you fail to propel your body over the bar.

So it is with our efforts to reach God.

God is perfect and his standard is perfection. Most of us have tried to earn our way to God.

But we are sinners. Our best effort on our best day falls short of God's perfect standard.

Respond
What are some of the things you have done to try to earn your way to God?

How has that worked out?

data.title: God Is with Us
data.content:
Several hundred years before the birth of Christ, Israel's political, moral, military, and spiritual pillars were crumbling. The prophet Isaiah didn't hold back on God's words of judgment. However, his messages included the promise of hope.

It's this promise of Isaiah that is referred to in Matthew 1:22-23. "All this took place to fulfill what the Lord had said through the prophet: 'The virgin will be with child and will give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel'--which means, 'God with us.'"

The Promise was not a politician, a military leader or religious leader. The Promise was Immanuel-- "God with us." Because through Jesus, God is with us forever!

data.title: The Lord Saves
data.content:
Do you know what that name Jesus means?

In Matthew 1:21 an angel explains to Joseph that Mary "will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus because he will save his people from their sins."

In Hebrew the name was "Joshua." In Greek the form changed to "Jesus." But in both languages the meaning was the same--"the Lord saves."

Today, people want "their savior" to get them a job, to fix their marriage, and so on. But each reason mentioned above is a symptom of a root problem. We need a Savior to save us from our sins. That's the eternal salvation that Jesus came to give us. Once our eternal salvation is in place, we can trust him with all the temporal issues of life.

data.title: Under the Influence
data.content:
Read
Don't be drunk with wine, because that will ruin your life. Instead, be filled with the Holy Spirit, singing psalms and hymns and spiritual songs among yourselves, and making music to the Lord in your hearts.
Ephesians 5:18-19

Reflect
The words "be filled" mean "to be controlled." It means to be influenced or empowered by the Holy Spirit. Paul uses a negative example to emphasize the meaning and significance. He compares and contrasts a person being filled with the Spirit to a person being drunk with wine.

A person under the influence of alcohol experienced blurred vision, slurred speech, slowed reaction, and skewed perception. Alcohol, taken in excess, is the controlling agent.

In the same way if you are filled with anger--the anger controls your life. If you are filled with bitterness--the bitterness controls your life. If you are filled with jealousy--the jealousy permeates all areas of your life. If you are filled with lust--you are controlled by your desires.

Paul's instruction is to abandon yourself to God and be controlled by His Spirit. Practically, there are two important points you need to understand regarding the filling of the Spirit.

1. Being filled with the Spirit is a command.

You are not instructed to be sealed by the Spirit. You are not instructed to be indwelt by the Spirit. You are commanded to be filled with the Spirit--living under the influence of the Spirit in all areas of your life.

2. The filling of the Spirit is ongoing.

The verb "be filled" is in the present tense--which means there must be a continuous application. You must keep on being filled, keep on being controlled.

Respond
Are you ready to abandon yourself to God today?

data.title: In Christ I Am Forgiven
data.content:
Read
He does not punish us for all our sins;
he does not deal harshly with us, as we deserve.
For his unfailing love toward those who fear him
is as great as the height of the heavens above the earth.
He has removed our sins as far from us
as the east is from the west.
Psalm 103:10-12

Reflect
Many believers carry within them the shame and guilt of past sin. This burden of the past weighs them down and holds them back from the present journey.

Satan wants to keep you paralyzed by the past. This paralysis renders you ineffective, but God reminds you over and over in Scripture that "in Christ" He dealt with our sin. His forgiveness frees you to live a life pleasing to him.

Consider these passages:
Isaiah 38:17
Isaiah 43:25
Isaiah 44:22
Micah 7:18-19

According to these verses what has God done with your sin?

data.title: Be a Telescope
data.content:
Philippians 1:21, here's what it says: "For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain."

The Apostle Paul wrote that, and he makes it clear that for him, life was not about stuff. Now, the "die is gain" part is easy to understand; who doesn't want eternity in heaven? But what about, "to live is Christ"?

I love the way Warren Wiersbe explains this. He asks: "What is bigger, a star or a telescope?" The answer is obvious. To most people, Jesus is like the star; a distant figure of history.

Christians are the telescope. "To live is Christ" means to be a telescope and bring God closer to people who have only considered Him from a distance.

data.title: Zapped
data.content:
I'm good at multi-tasking. For instance, I can vacuum the family room and mentally go over all of my husband's faults at the same time. I can even prepare a lecture in my mind detailing all the ways he needs to change.

God is a multi-tasker, too. He can watch me do all that, listen to my litany of complaints AND bonk me over the head with the truth without even breaking a sweat. And the truth is this: I can't change my husband. I can only change my attitude.

My big a-ha moment while vacuuming came when I realized that my list of complaints about my husband was the same list I'd been going over for my entire marriage. In fact, it's the same list I had before we got married. Which meant that on the day I said "I do", I did so knowing his faults--and I committed my life to him anyway.

It suddenly occurred to me that day that it was pretty unfair to expect him to live up to my standards when I had promised to love and cherish him knowing he wasn't perfect. If I had remembered at my wedding ceremony when they read 1 Corinthians I would have already known that. "[Love] does not demand its own way. It is not irritable, and it keeps no record of being wronged." (13:5-6)

Boy had I blown that one. At times I had very nearly developed a "my way or the highway" attitude. I'd definitely been irritable. In fact, irritable is putting it nicely. And the record of his wrongs was lengthy and detailed.

It hasn't happened very often that God has completely zapped my thinking out of nowhere, so I paid attention. It pains me to think of the years of our marriage that I spent trying to change my husband and then punishing him when he wouldn't or couldn't live up to the bar I had set.

I resolved that day to let it go; to focus on his strengths as a husband and leave the weaknesses to God. Of course I slip up more than I'd like, but overall I'd have to say that we're both a lot happier.

Focusing on his patience not his procrastination,
Jennifer

data.title: It's ok
data.content:
All the best people are neurotic and insecure. Screwed up. Sewed up. Turned up. Fixed up. Well, by the best people, I simply mean all people. Look at us.

For the longest time I thought I was the only one who hated middle school. I remember pretending to like a boy named John Glass simply because answering "who do you like?" with "nobody" for the twentieth time was like a thumping reminder that I was a nice, boring loner. I was deeply insecure.

And even now. All the people I've ever met. There we are. Still neurotic. Still insecure.

And it's ok.

It's ok. And...

That little dot dot dot takes us, like the little path it resembles, to something better.

Thank God we can get more used to ourselves the longer we live. We can learn not to be hostile or accommodating or quiet or obnoxious or separated or whatever it is that we do to cope with our insecurities. It's such a relief.

Liberating.

It's liberating for it to be ok to be who you are...and to not stay the same person forever.

"We know how much God loves us, and we have put our trust in his love. God is love, and all who live in love live in God, and God lives in them. And as we live in God, our love grows more perfect" (1 John 4:16-17).

Em

data.title: Still
data.content:
"I realize that someday I may not even be able to touch her." he said to me, looking down like his love was heavy against the gravity of the earth. Angie had a rare disease, similar to congenital analgesia, only instead of not feeling pain when she touched a hot stove or scraped her foot on a rock, Angie would feel intense pain when nothing was happening. A boy had thrown a chair at her in third grade. For whatever reason, it messed up her nervous system to the point that something as normal as taking a shower felt like, in her words, "knives stabbing me all over my back." Horrible.

It was this girl that had won the heart of my friend. "I love her," he said. And he did love her. He wanted to marry her. Her and all the things that would mean. Love wrapped up in kindness and sacrifice. Unbelievably so.

"It's weird how things shape you" another friend said to me, "I can't date a girl without thinking, is this a girl I could sit next to through cancer?"

For me it is, is this somebody I would love even if he was bouncing checks? And pubs? And towns?

And of course. It's a burning thing. To say you will love somebody like that.

In the Bible there’s a word that's tough to translate. So tough, in fact, that more than one scholar has simply refused to do it. Hesed. It means love. Tender love. Kind. Penetrating. Unbelievably persistent. Love without the function of return. Love even when it is undeserved. Love like a covenant.

Read Psalm 136--"ki le'olam hesed." You'll read it over and over and over. Because his faithful love endures forever. Because his loving-kindness endures forever. Because his persistent, loyal, penetrating love endures forever.

And really only him.

"People are like the grass. Their hesed fades as quickly as the flowers in a field...but the word of our God stands forever" (Isaiah 40:6, 8).

He knows we don't love like him. Our love fades like the flowers in a field. He knows we screw up. That we vomit all over ourselves from the things we choose. But his love endures.

Still.

Em

data.title: The Unseen
data.content:
And I kick my feet. I run down the stairs, use crude words in a loud voice and turn my back to him. This is how I act when I don't get my way. There are voices in my head saying how selfish my husband's being. They say, "Look at him sitting there, doing whatever he wants, while you have to go do this all by yourself."

How unbelievably soon I forget. It's like my mind purposely erases the millions of times my husband has sacrificed for me...like it wants me to forget. Like he's some cranky, horrible old man who's determined to set fire to every good memory I have and leave me with only the dreadful ones.

In the fifth Harry Potter movie, Harry yells out to the evil guy, Voldemort, something like this, "But you'll never know love, or friendship. And I feel sorry for you." Fictional moments like these often cause me to reflect on ways they reveal truth.

Satan knows he's going to be destroyed. He'll never know love or friendship and he's determined to make as many of us suffer with him as he can. It will take struggles and seemingly endless battles, but we have to fight. We have to dig with our bare hands through the mud and find those moments where those we love have loved us in return. We cannot let ourselves sulk and stand under the pelting rainfall. Or we will be lost in misery. And evil will have little work left to do in keeping us far from God.

"Put on all of God's armor so that you will be able to stand firm against all strategies of the devil. For we are not fighting against flesh-and-blood enemies, but against evil rulers and authorities of the unseen world, against mighty powers in this dark world, and against evil spirits in the heavenly places" (Ephesians 6:10-12).

Belts of truth and a body armor of righteousness. Shoes made of peace. Faith as our shield against the devil's arrows. The truth of God's salvation guards our minds, and our weapons are his promises.

And to think, I used to find this armor stuff corny.

June
