data.title: The Value in Forgiving
data.content:
My husband Mark's father was a piece of work. The town knew him as the county judge. His wife and four kids knew him as an alcoholic who all but ignored them except to fling insults and the occasional fist. As the oldest, Mark took more than his fair share of the abuse.

Mark left for college at 18 and met up with a group of people who led him to Christ. I believe it saved his life. He held on to the idea of a Father who loved him unconditionally and he healed. He even reached a place where he could not only forgive his dad, but build a relationship of sorts with him.

When Mark's dad died in a car wreck four years after Mark left home, each of the kids dealt with it differently. Mark's brother Rick has chosen not to forgive, but rather to whitewash his dad's behavior and pretend things weren't that bad. Rick has followed his dad's footsteps into alcoholism and rage.

Mark's baby sister also chooses to remember only the good. She contends that her dad only abused her siblings--not her. The string of alcoholic, abusive boyfriends tells another story.

And finally, Mark's other sister has chosen a different path completely. She holds on to her anger at her dad with a tight fist. She remembers none of the good and goes over the bad like a well-paged book. Her bitterness spills over into all of her relationships and affects her physical health.

Mark is the only one fortunate enough to understand the power of forgiveness.

"Do not condemn others, or it will all come back against you. Forgive others, and you will be forgiven. Give, and you will receive. Your gift will return to you in full--pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, running over, and poured into your lap. The amount you give will determine the amount you get back" (Luke 6:37-38).

Mark gave his forgiveness and in return has lived a life largely free of the bondage his siblings experience. I am so grateful that my marriage and my kids don't have to be on the list of my father-in-law's victims.

I am so grateful Mark chose to forgive.

Freed from the sins of the father,
Jennifer

data.title: Log
data.content:
"Do not judge others, and you will not be judged... How can you think of saying to your friend, 'Let me help you get rid of that speck in your eye,' when you can't see past the log in your own eye? Hypocrite! First get rid of the log in your own eye; then you will see well enough to deal with the speck in your friend's eye" (Matthew 7:1, 3-5).

"Judgmental" is a harsh word. So, naturally, I call myself "analytical" instead. I spend a lot of time analyzing. I analyze my husband's behavior--whether he's engaged or distant. I analyze his interactions with our daughter. I analyze my daughter's attitudes and behavior. I analyze myself--how I look, feel, perform. You could say I'm highly analytical.

My "analysis" has become a sort of obsessive need to correct. I want everyone around me to behave in a way that creates wellbeing. I often think things like, If my husband would just...--fill in the blank with whatever behavior he seems to have missed that particular evening--we would be happy.

I was talking with a friend of mine about this tendency, and she wisely pointed out that perhaps "analytical" wasn't the right word to describe my attitude. She wondered if "judgmental" might be more apt. Then she said that she was dealing with something similar recently and read Matthew 7:1-5. She wondered if the log the verses refer to is judgment itself. This was new to me. I'd always thought of the log as some huge, unmentionable sin that I would certainly never commit.

But I think she's got a solid point. The log of judgment keeps me from seeing anyone around me clearly. In fact, the log seems to splinter into specks so that everyone I see is somehow contaminated by my judgment. I think maybe getting rid of the log in my own eye will clear up the specks I see in everyone else as well.

Ellen

data.title: The Final Word
data.content:
I sigh and examine my fingernails as my husband talks with the saleswoman. She is unable to answer a single question we have about the tan sofa we are considering. "I'm sorry," she stutters, "I don't usually work in furniture." My husband thanks her. I sigh again and cross my arms over my chest.

"Why aren't we getting the couch?" my son asks.

"Because the lady has absolutely no information, despite the fact that she is supposedly an employee of this store," I hiss. The saleswoman's heels click across the tile. I see her glance back at me.

"Rachel!" Andrew admonishes. "Keep your voice down! She can hear you, you know." My husband is appalled, but I don't care. We've been looking for a sofa for two months. I've visited this store three times, each time leaving without the information I need. I want to blame someone, and the innocent saleswoman is my target.

As we leave, I feel the tendrils of guilt and regret wrap around my gut. By the time Andrew pulls the car into the driveway, I am in full self-condemnation mode.

I berate myself for days after the furniture store incident. I know God forgives me, I simply cannot forgive myself. The power of my sin grips me with a suffocating stranglehold, like a metal vise around my chest.

Until, that is, I remember that Jesus does not condemn me--that nothing separates me from his love and forgiveness, not even my ugliest sin.

"So now there is no condemnation for those who belong to Christ," Paul writes to the Romans. "And because you belong to him, the power of the life-giving Spirit has freed you from the power of sin that leads to death" (Romans 8:1-2).

I know I will sin again, but at the same time, my commitment to Jesus ensures that I am not controlled by my sinful nature (Romans 8:9). Jesus' sacrifice on the cross lifted the power of sin, freeing me not only from unending shame and guilt, but, more importantly, from the strangulating hold of sin on my life. Trusting that I am loved and forgiven by Jesus allows me to live unburdened and at peace, because he promises that sin does not have the final word.

Rachel

data.title: Shout for Joy
data.content:
If you're like me, sometimes prayer times can become heavy on requests and light on thanksgiving. If that's you, listen to this passage from Psalm 100:1-3.

"Shout for joy to the LORD, all the earth. Worship the LORD with gladness; come before him with joyful songs. Know that the LORD is God. It is he who made us, and we are his; we are his people, the sheep of his pasture."

You see, we belong to the God who loves us so much that He sent His Son to die for our sins. Because of Jesus "we are his people" just as the Psalm says! That truth alone deserves a shout for joy, joyful worship and the singing of some joyful songs.

data.title: A Different Spirit
data.content:
After exploring the Promised Land, ten of the twelve scouts reported, "We can't attack those people; they are stronger than we are."

Joshua and Caleb, the other two scouts had a different response. Here's their response in Numbers 14:8-9:

"If the LORD is pleased with us, he will lead us into that land, a land flowing with milk and honey, and will give it to us. Only do not rebel against the LORD. And do not be afraid of the people of the land.... Their protection is gone, but the LORD is with us."

Many challenges in life seem bigger than you are--in fact, they are bigger! However, they are not bigger than the God we serve.

data.title: Be Strong Be Courageous
data.content:
After Moses died, the assignment of leading Israel into the Promised Land was on Joshua's shoulders. The weight was heavy!

But in Joshua 1:9, we read these words of encouragement from God: "Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged, for the LORD your God will be with you wherever you go."

God's instruction is clear, isn't it? "Be strong!" "Be courageous!" "Don't be afraid!" "Don't be discouraged!" God's commands are not without a foundation. In fact, He is the foundation!

Wherever you go, whatever you're going through, whenever you are afraid, He is right there with you. He will never leave you, He will never forsake you.

data.title: Only Be Still
data.content:
Fresh from being delivered out of slavery, the Israelites were caught between the powerful Egyptians and the Red Sea. No wonder they were terrified. In Exodus 14:12 we hear their cry of fear: "It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert."

But Moses calmed them with these words, "Do not be afraid. Stand firm and you will see the deliverance the LORD will bring you today... The LORD will fight for you; you need only to be still."

What waves of fear and doubt are rolling through your life today? You don't have to try to stand up under the force of the crashing waves. The Lord will absorb the powerful force for you. You need only to be still.

data.title: Forever Faithful
data.content:
What gives you confidence? A thriving economy? A secure job?

Check out today's passage in Psalm 146:3-6.

"Do not put your trust in princes, in human beings, who cannot save. When their spirit departs, they return to the ground; on that very day their plans come to nothing. Blessed are those whose help is the God of Jacob, whose hope is in the LORD their God. He is the Maker of heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them--he remains faithful forever."

No person can deliver security. So put your trust in the One who remains faithful forever. The only One who can stand with you throughout eternity.

data.title: You Are There
data.content:
In Psalm 139:7-10, we read this about God:

David, the psalmist asks: "Where can I go from your Spirit? Where can I flee from your presence? If I go up to the heavens, you are there; if I make my bed in the depths, you are there. If I rise on the wings of the dawn, if I settle on the far side of the sea, even there your hand will guide me, your right hand will hold me fast."

God is not limited by time or space. He is present everywhere at the same time in His whole being. And because of God's omnipresence we are never alone. He is present in our laughter and He's right there with us in our tears. He never leaves us, He never forsakes us.

data.title: In the Garden
data.content:
They went to the olive grove called Gethsemane, and Jesus said, "Sit here while I go and pray." He took Peter, James, and John with him, and he became deeply troubled and distressed. He told them, "My soul is crushed with grief to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch with me."...

Then Jesus left them again and prayed the same prayer as before. When he returned to them again, he found them sleeping, for they couldn't keep their eyes open. And they didn't know what to say.
Mark 14:32-34,39-40

data.title: Though the Mountains Quake
data.content:
Sometimes we experience what might be called an earthquake of the soul: our world is shaken. Yet when these inevitable times occur, we can stand strong. Really? Can we stand strong?

The psalmist reminds us in Psalm 46:1-3 that, "God is our refuge and strength, an ever-present help in trouble. Therefore we will not fear, though the earth gives way and the mountains fall into the heart of the sea, though its waters roar and foam and the mountains quake with their surging."

God is our shelter of protection. God alone is our refuge and strength, and He is ever-present. People will come and go. But our God will never leave us, will never forsake us.

data.title: My Strength My Shield
data.content:
Ever feel like you don't measure up? Ever feel like life's assignment is beyond your skill level?

In Psalm 28:1 David readily admits he doesn't have what it takes. If God didn't come to his aid, and quick, he concluded, "I will be like those who go down to the pit"

Real adequacy--the ability to meet each challenge and opportunity of life--must come from the Lord. Listen to how David finishes his prayer in Psalm 28:7: "The LORD is my strength and my shield; my heart trusts in him, and he helps me. My heart leaps for joy, and with my song I praise him."

What do you need to trust God for today? That's the real question, isn't it?

data.title: Do the Work
data.content:
In 1 Chronicles 28:20, we read these words from David written to his son Solomon:

"'Be strong and courageous, and do the work. Do not be afraid or discouraged, for the LORD God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or forsake you until all the work for the service of the temple of the LORD is finished.'"

Solomon had some serious challenges ahead of him, but David's charge to him was "Be strong and courageous, and do the work." God would always be with him.

We have the same promise. God is with us! Be strong and courageous, and press on to do the work that God has for you to do. He will always give you exactly what you need to do what He is calling you to do.

data.title: Trinity
data.content:
All right, the Trinity? God in three Persons? Why not the "binity?" God in two persons? Or why not 16 persons? Well the truth is, it's three. One God in three Persons.

One God in three Persons gives us a glimpse into the perfect community that God enjoys. Here are a few instances where the Bible talks about it.

John 6:27

But don"t be so concerned about perishable things like food. Spend your energy seeking the eternal life that the Son of Man can give you. For God the Father has given me the seal of his approval.

Colossians 1:17-19

He existed before anything else,
and he holds all creation together.
Christ is also the head of the church,
which is his body.
He is the beginning,
supreme over all who rise from the dead.
So he is first in everything.
For God in all his fullness
was pleased to live in Christ.

1 Corinthians 2:10-12

But it was to us that God revealed these things by his Spirit. For his Spirit searches out everything and shows us God's deep secrets. No one can know a person's thoughts except that person's own spirit, and no one can know God's thoughts except God's own Spirit. And we have received God's Spirit (not the world's spirit), so we can know the wonderful things God has freely given us.

Don't worry, you'll never quite get your mind around it. That's why God is God. But take comfort in knowing that God loves you, and those Persons are working together to redeem the world.

data.title: Justification
data.content:
Read
Yet it was our weaknesses he carried;
it was our sorrows that weighed him down.
And we thought his troubles were a punishment from God,
a punishment for his own sins!
But he was pierced for our rebellion,
crushed for our sins.
He was beaten so we could be whole.
He was whipped so we could be healed.
All of us, like sheep, have strayed away.
We have left God's paths to follow our own.
Yet the LORD laid on him
the sins of us all.
Isaiah 53:4-6


He was delivered over to death for our sins and was raised to life for our justification.
Romans 4:25

Reflect
"Justification" is a legal term with two eternal benefits. First, you are declared "Not Guilty!" Because Jesus paid the penalty for your sin on the cross, you are acquitted. Second, God declared you righteous. Because of Jesus you no longer fall short of God's perfect standard. Jesus bridged the separation between God and you. Therefore, you can have complete confidence to stand before God when you die and be welcomed into heaven. Christ's death completely covers the penalty of your sin and His righteousness is credited to you.

Respond
Spend some time today thinking about what Jesus did for you on the cross.

data.title: Lost Sheep
data.content:
Read
So Jesus told them this story: "If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them gets lost, what will he do? Won't he leave the ninety-nine others in the wilderness and go to search for the one that is lost until he finds it? And when he has found it, he will joyfully carry it home on his shoulders. When he arrives, he will call together his friends and neighbors, saying, 'Rejoice with me because I have found my lost sheep.' In the same way, there is more joy in heaven over one lost sinner who repents and returns to God than over ninety-nine others who are righteous and haven't strayed away!"
Luke 15:3-7

Reflect
Jesus answered the Pharisees' complaints about welcoming sinners with three parables about grace. In the first, a shepherd learned that one of his sheep was lost. He searched and searched until he found the lost sheep. When the man found the sheep, he was so overjoyed that he called his friends and neighbors to share the good news and invited them to rejoice with him. Such is the power of grace.

Respond
What does this parable show you about grace?

data.title: Jesus Died for your Sins
data.content:
Read
Once you were dead because of your disobedience and your many sins. You used to live in sin, just like the rest of the world, obeying the devil--the commander of the powers in the unseen world. He is the spirit at work in the hearts of those who refuse to obey God. All of us used to live that way, following the passionate desires and inclinations of our sinful nature. By our very nature we were subject to God’s anger, just like everyone else.

But God is so rich in mercy, and he loved us so much, that even though we were dead because of our sins, he gave us life when he raised Christ from the dead. (It is only by God’s grace that you have been saved!)
Ephesians 2:1-5

Reflect
God sent Jesus to do for us what we could not do for ourselves. Jesus was fully-God and fully-man. This is called the Incarnation. Being God, He could meet the perfect standard; He could jump over the bar. Being man, He voluntarily paid the wages of your sin with His death on the cross.

In this passage, Paul describes sinners as spiritual corpses. Physically speaking, those dead in their sins go about their day, do their work, enjoy their recreation, and raise their families. But spiritually speaking, they are lifeless, flat-lined, and incapably of movement.

Respond
What friend of yours needs you to share God's mercy today?

data.title: Living for God: Basic Instructions
data.content:
Do you want to live the way God wants you to? Well then, listen to this.

Ephesians 4:26-29

And "don't sin by letting anger control you." Don't let the sun go down while you are still angry, for anger gives a foothold to the devil. If you are a thief, quit stealing. Instead, use your hands for good hard work, and then give generously to others in need. Don't use foul or abusive language. Let everything you say be good and helpful, so that your words will be an encouragement to those who hear them.

This is pretty basic, right? Be careful about the words that literally come out of your mouth or even snarky comments online. It's one really important way to live how God wants you to and that makes the world a better place.
